However what really drives me is to explore the potential of the whole system. Will the timber trees do better with a coppiced alder next to them? Will our soil health improve? Can we demonstrate improved productivity of the whole farm as many agroforestry systems do?” Soil erosion is one of the most concerning. This happens when soil is washed and blown away by rain and wind. Some 3 million tons of topsoil are lost in the UK each year, according to the Campaign to Protect Rural England. And British soils may have only 100 harvests left, warn scientists from the University of Sheffield.&nbspBut trees protect soil: their roots provide stabilising infrastructure, creating channels where water is held, while their bodies act&nbspas wind-blockers. These factors will come in even more useful with the increasingly violent floods and storms caused by climate change. In a few decades’ time, we may be relying on agroforestry techniques just to ensure we can still feed ourselves.&nbspThe roots of trees also dig deeper than crops, allowing them to bring up more nutrients&nbsp – mainly nitrogen, phosphorus and potassium – from below. The nutrients spread to the leaves, which then fall on the soil and feed crops, if they are being grown alongside. This is nature’s fertiliser and could help farmers cut their pesticide costs as well as revitalise tired, one-crop fields.&nbspEastbrook Farm in Wiltshire lets its organic pigs&nbsprootle around under trees instead of fields&nbsp(Emily Clark)Trees also provide habitats for wildlife down in the earth’s crust and above it – giving home to the birds, critters and insects that are in alarming decline in Britain, whose existence we depend upon for our ecosystem.And crucially, trees suck up carbon, which is why planting them is key to the government’s climate strategy. More and more, trees are hitting headlines as solutions to our climate crisis. The government advisers at the Committee on Climate Change say 30,000 hectares of woodland should be planted every year until 2050 to meet the UK’s goal of net zero carbon at that point. That’s 1.5 billion trees in total.Farmers have come to see trees as a problem rather than something of value. If you’ve got a big oak tree in the middle of your field, you don’t think, ‘It’s great to have a habitat for all the stuff around oak trees’, you think, ‘I’ve got to bloody drive round that in my plough’The committee, made up of science and business experts, adds that the 30,000 hectare figure may have to be revised up to 50,000 if other climate promises aren’t met.&nbspLast year, England was 7 million trees short of the target for just 5,000 hectares, so there will have to be huge changes to keep us on track – putting agroforestry in the spotlight. It’s likely that the benefits of tree planting will align with the environment-focused farming subsidies that replace the EU payments after Brexit.There are still more benefits from farm trees – animals allowed to graze among them are given shade and shelter. This means they need less feed to keep warm or cool, and gives them a wider diet. The fruit, nuts, fuel logs or timber from trees and bushes then create another income stream for farmers.&nbspWith all this, you would think farmers would be keen on agroforestry. But modern farming, which has crept up on us since the industrial revolution and inspired today’s chemical-soaked monocrops, has seen farmers become reluctant to keep hedges, bushes and trees.&nbspMany tore these wilder spaces up so they could profit from crops instead – every inch of field matters when margins are tight. In our mad farming subsidy matrix, which encourages farming with yield-boosting pesticides, who could blame them? (Tearing out long farm hedgerows did become illegal in 1997.)Our version of capitalism has also created incentive to farm lots of one thing – high street chains and supermarkets want to make life easy for themselves by having fewer suppliers who can deliver bulk orders. But eventually, the huge monocrop fields that are fuelled on chemicals will become infertile, and what then?The good news is that, if done carefully, planting trees can boost productivity by up to a third, according to the Soil Association (SA). It can be done in an environmentally sustainable way that also makes financial sense.When cows munch on tree leaves, their&nbspdiet is improved and tree growth is stimulated –&nbspmulberry leaves are high in protein and willow bark has painkilling properties. Or when chickens trample down the weeds around young trees, they are stifling the competition. As with the hens and raspberries, animal manure then fertilises the soil – helping trees or crops grow.&nbspFarmers were being paid to rip out hedges so that fields got bigger. As a result we’ve now got lots of really big fields, with nothing but one crop in it, which is actually quite a vulnerable, fragile position to be inBut before taking the risk of buying trees and rethinking their farm systems, farmers need sound advice to know what’s best for their animals or crops. There are a million agroforestry variations, and a million factors – soil type, tree species, choice of animal, grazing time, fencing, market demands, wind direction, labour costs, stubborn landowners… pass the paracetamol.&nbspThis is a long game, and the financial stakes are high – it can take 10 to 15 years to establish a raspberry cane, and growing oak for timber can take 100 years.But there is advice out there. Ben Raskin, head of horticulture at the SA, is in his third year of testing out more than 20 tree species at Eastbrook Farm in Wiltshire – belonging to SA chief executive Helen Browning. He oversaw the raspberry and chicken combination, just one example of his many devious schemes.&nbspHe’s particularly excited about growing almonds and apricots (now feasible thanks to global warming) in a location that hasn’t been tried before… in other words, California dreamin’. Raskin has now put together a handbook for farmers explaining how to move into agroforestry, produced by the SA and the Farm Woodland Forum.&nbspHe says at least one farmer a week comes over to ask about his agroforestry experiments – four came the week before I visited, with 1,000 acres between them, and officials from Defra were booked in the following week.&nbspRaskin&nbspis encouraging farmers to branch out with the tree species they&nbspchoose to plant&nbsp(Emily Clark)Before showing me his neat rows of young trees including peach, pear, cherry and damson, he explains why this type of farming is blossoming in Britain – after 150 years of decline.&nbsp“Long, long ago, farmers would have made quite a lot of use of trees, and hedgerows would have been quite productive,” he says. “They would have had fruit and nuts and they would have coppiced them for fuel.”As industrialisation took hold, and farmers began to specialise, the story changed. “We were getting bigger tractors and becoming more efficient at farming,” Raskin says, “so farmers were being paid to rip out hedges so that fields got bigger. As a result we’ve now got lots of really big fields, with nothing but one crop in it, which is actually quite a vulnerable, fragile position to be in.How small farms are leading the way towards sustainable agricultureFarming chief calls for ‘net zero’ agriculture emissions in UK by 2040‘Super crops’ could revolutionise agriculture in Africa, expert claims“Farmers have come to see trees as a problem rather than something of value, something that’s worth spending time on. If you’ve got a big oak tree in the middle of your field, you don’t think, ‘It’s great to have a habitat for all the stuff around oak trees’, you think, ‘I’ve got to bloody drive round that in my plough’. However, trees do bring a whole massive range of benefits to a farm.”&nbspA lot of countries are way ahead of us on this, he says, including France, China, America&nbspand tropical countries that never lost the art. In Spain and Portugal’s dehesa systems, pigs are mixed in with cork and oak trees, feeding on the acorns.&nbspRaskin points to a few agroforestry operations in the UK – the Pontbren lamb project in Wales involving 10 farmers is one that has been a particular success. They realised during the Nineties that they were spending too much on feed and housing costs for their lambs. To keep the lambs outside for longer, they knew the animals would need more shelter – so they began planting thousands of trees.&nbspTheir plans worked. But the farmers also realised that the woodland absorbed 60 times more water than pasture fields just 10 metres away. The trees they had planted in the wettest parts of Wales were a brilliant defence against flooding in other parts of the country.&nbspThere were also fewer chemicals running into waterways from compacted soils on intensive farms. And better shelter is&nbspknown to&nbspreduce flock health issues, such as lameness or even death of the youngest lambs.But Raskin says there are still very few examples of agroforestry in the UK – and we’ve got to up our game.&nbspWith the barrage of difficulties faced by our farmers, especially as Brexit uproots the subsidy system, they’re going to need all the help they can get. Trees might be the perfect way to branch out.Only the best news in your inboxOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsUnusual little lifeforms could live for yearsClick to followThe Independent TechThere may be life on the Moon.A spacecraft that crashed landed on the lunar surface have spilled tiny bugs across it, which may have&nbspseeded&nbspit with life.What's more, the new residents are tardigrades – considered the most resilient life form on Earth, they could be able to survive on the alien surface of the Moon.The visitors made their way to the Moon on board the Beresheet probe, which was designed to become the first private lander to successfully arrive on the surface. When it arrived in April, however, it crashed, and the mission was aborted.For most people and the majority of the mission, that catastrophic event brought everything to a close. But the tardigrades – true to their reputation for being hardy – might have survived the crashed and been spread across the surface, where they could be living on today.Created with Sketch.Best NASA pictures of the month - July 2019 Show all 10Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.A total solar eclipse as seen from the US National Science Federation observatory in the Chilean Andes on 2 JulyA composite image of the Cygnus OB2 star cluster composed of pictures taken by the Isaac Newton Telescope and Spitzer Space Telescope on July 24The spacecraft Soyuz MS-13 is launched at the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan on July 20A copy of LIFE magazine from July 4 1969 signed by Michael Collins is seen onboard the Soyuz spacecraftThe galaxy NGC 1156 which is said to resemble a cherry blossom tree. He and his organisation loaded the Beresheet lander up with a library that could serve as a summary of life on Earth: 30 million pages of information, samples of human DNA, and the tardigrades.Tardigrades were first discovered in the 18th century, and have fascinated scientists ever since. They are tiny, measuring just half a milimetre long, and are found all around Earth.Much of the reason for the fascination is just how able they are to withstand extreme environments and survive. They have shown the ability to be exposed to very high and low temperatures, intense pressure, as well as being deprived of air, food and water, as well as already demonstrating that they can live after being put in outer space.They do that party by going into a very strange hibernation, where they can switch off a variety of biological processes and then restart them again when they wake back up. They could be doing that on the Moon, scientists warn, ready to be revived when conditions are right.As such, scientists don't think that the tardigrades will be thriving on the Moon. But they could be waiting there ready to be picked up and revived, they say, and could stay in that state for years.On other planets that could potentially be home to life, Nasa and other space agencies are very careful about contaminating the surface with life from the Earth. But the Moon is considered dead and so restrictions are much less – with Apollo astronauts leaving bacteria there in the fecal matter they dropped on the surface.Be inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsBe inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: pound live dollar euro exchange rate brexit no deal gbp usd
story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsFollow the latest business updatesClick to followThe IndependentThe pound is set to fall even further as the likelihood increases of a no-deal Brexit that will be disastrous for the UK economy, according to a poll.Sterling has already suffered a rout since Boris Johnson became prime minister on 24 July, falling to a two-and-a-half year low against the dollar of $1.2080 last week.Analysts polled by Reuters predicted further declines to between $1.17 and $1.20 as the 31 October deadline day approaches.Please allow a moment for the live blog to loadWhile interest rates and economic data would normally drive the value of the pound, right now the primary factor by a long distance is the perceived probability that the UK will leave the EU with no deal on 31 October.&nbspThe more likely it appears to be, the lower the pound goes.&nbspThis morning brings news of another plan MPs have hatched to prevent that outcome, which a majority of them - and the public - want to avoid.&nbspMPs are considering a bid to cancel the annual autumn recess set aside for party conferences in a fresh attempt to prevent Boris Johnson ploughing ahead with a no-deal Brexit, our political correspondent Ashley Cowburn reports.&nbspBrexit: MPs considering bid to ‘cancel autumn recess’ to stop Halloween no-dealSome better news today in stock markets that have suffered recently from fears surrounding an escalating trade war between the US&nbspand China.&nbspThe major indices edged up on the back of&nbspsurprise news that Chinese exports rose 3.3 per cent in July, despite rising tariffs imposed by Donald Trump's administration.&nbspImports were also up suggesting China is showing signs of resilience.&nbsp&nbsp- Japan's Nikkei 225 up 0.37 per cent to 20,593.35.&nbsp- Hong Kong's Hang Seng up 0.5 per cent to 26,120.77&nbsp- Germany's Dax up 0.5 per cent to 11,712.12&nbsp- France's CAC 40 up 1 per cent to 5,317.74&nbsp- FTSE 100 up 0.14 per cent to 7,208.62What would the economy look like after a no-deal Brexit with&nbspone&nbsppound worth less than one dollar?&nbspPretty dreadul, according to Silvia Dall’Angelo, Senior Economist at Hermes Investment Management:&nbspA sharp currency depreciation would act as a supply-side shock, driving a spike in inflation, a squeeze on income and a drag on consumption. Savings would fail to provide an ample buffer as consumers have already dissaved significantly since the EU referendum. In fact, the saving rate is running close to its record low levels.&nbsp&nbspBusiness investment may also slow further as a falling pound with potential for further depreciation could spook investors. Furthermore, the benefit of rising exports usually associated with a weaker currency has not yet been felt by UK businesses, which suggests we may see little boost to exports from a weak pound.&nbspLooking beyond pound v dollar, things are even worse for the pound.&nbspAgainst a trade-weighted basket of major currencies, sterling hit a 33-month low on 30 July&nbspSterling’s recent tumble suggests that a no-deal Brexit could take the pound into uncharted territory, says&nbspSilvia Dall’Angelo, Senior Economist at Hermes Investment Management.&nbspAgainst the dollar, that could mean $1.05 to $1.10 but, Given the tendency for financial markets to overshoot, no-deal Brexit could easily push the pound to parity with the dollar which has never happened before.&nbspShe adds:&nbspGoing forward, there is scope for wider ranges of value for the pound, including the possibility of an increase if MPs are able to successfully block a no-deal Brexit in Parliament, but realistically, the next few months don’t hold much promise for the currency. &nbspSeptember and October could be wildly volatile months for sterling.&nbspGood morning and welcome to The Independent's live coverage of business and economics events around the world.&nbsp&nbspAnalysts are predicting that the pound, already battered by Boris Johnson's premiership, is set to fall further in the coming weeks.&nbspHouse prices are also suffering in the Brexit gloom, according to a poll of surveyors.Only the best news in your inboxOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Nicola Sturgeon said by late next year or the beginning of 2021.”Reacting to the comments, the Scottish Labour MP Ian Murray&nbsptold the BBC: “Why John McDonnell has cross the border to go to the Edinburgh Festival Fringe to change a massive constitutional policy on the hoof is completely beyond me.”Venting his frustration, he continued: “We’ve had no explanation from John McDonnell, apart from him doubling down again today, of why he would even consider an off the cuff remark on this policy. Even if he wants to change policy, we are supposed to be a democratic party.&nbsp“Where is the Scottish Labour Party members’ input into this massive constitutional change in policy?&nbsp“He has a lot to explain, but firstly I think he should apologise to Richard Leonard, because Richard Leonard is right. The policy is no to a second independence referendum.”Labour’s manifesto at the 2017 general election claimed independence in Scotland would “lead to turbocharged austerity for Scottish families”.“Labour opposes a second Scottish independence referendum. It is unwanted and unnecessary, and we will campaign tirelessly to ensure Scotland remains part of the UK.”Nicola Sturgeon, a new Scottish referendum will be worse than BrexitBrexit paves way for Scottish independence, Sturgeon saysRees Mogg says Scotland not due independence referendum for 20 yearsSturgeon says second independence referendum will hinge on BrexitIntervening in the row, Labour MP Stella Creasy added: “Nationalism is antithesis of socialism – to prioritise passports over principles isn’t progressive.“Egalitarian devolution isn’t about separation but how by working together as nations within the UK each stronger and more successful. Labour abandons such commitment at our peril.”And seizing on the comments, the Scottish Conservative leader Ruth Davidson said Mr McDonnell’s remarks were met with “complete dismay” by Labour voters in Scotland.&nbspEchoing attack lines used by the Tories at the 2015 general election against the then-leader Ed Miliband, Ms Davidson said the shadow chancellor’s comments signalled Labour’s intention to propose a pact with the SNP to “parachute Jeremy Corbyn into No 10”.&nbsp“The fact is this – Jeremy Corbyn and John McDonnell would happily sell Scotland down the river if they thought it could give them a sniff of power,” she added.The latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxThe latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Morgan hit 17 sixes and set a new record in one-day international cricket, which saw his side win by 150 runsBut why is&nbspScottish independence in the headlines again?The short answer is because of Boris Johnson’s arrival in Downing Street, shifting the government’s Brexit stance towards a no-deal departure.Mr Johnson has tried to put the preservation of&nbspthe UK at the heart of his premiership, by visiting the devolved governments early and by describing himself as “minister for the union”.However, his visit to Edinburgh, where he was booed and jeered by protesters, seems to have done more harm than good.A shock&nbsppoll, conducted in the wake of his trip, put backing for&nbspScottish independence&nbspat 46 per cent, with 43 per cent of voters against.Support for independence rose to 52 per cent, with 48 per cent against, when those who said they did not know how they would vote or said they would not vote were removed.The poll by Lord Ashcroft –&nbspthe first to show a lead for Scottish independence since 2017 – had a major impact.Nicola Sturgeon, the Scottish first minister, said it delivered a “phenomenal” boost for the independence movement, as Scotland was “dragged towards a no-deal Brexit”.While it is only one poll, the Ashcroft findings illustrate the growing threat to the union from a no-deal Brexit.By law, Scotland must seek the UK government’s approval to hold another referendum, as matters relating to the union of the United Kingdom are referred to Westminster.Majority of Scots back independence in shock poll after Johnson visitAfter the 2014 vote, Sturgeon&nbspkept her troops at the top of the hill for some time.She eventually requested consent from Theresa May in March 2017, the day before the then-prime minister fired the starting gun on the Brexit process.May blocked the move, saying it was “not the time” for more constitutional upheaval. Sturgeon tried again in April 2019 but the request was again denied.In May, the Scottish government published a bill laying out the framework for a second independence referendum once it has been granted powers by Westminster.Using a similar framework to previous referendums, the bill would allow a new vote quickly as Holyrood would not need to pass another law. The question and the date would need parliamentary approval under the plan.If the referendum question were the same as in the 2014 poll,&nbspthere would be no need for further testing by the Electoral Commission.There is a small majority for independence in the Scottish parliament, as the&nbspScottish Greens would join the SNP to form a 68-strong bloc in the 129-seat parliament.All of the remaining Holyrood&nbspparties are opposed to Scotland leaving the UK.The problem for Sturgeon is all her preparations hinge on getting the nod from Westminster – and that remains an unlikely prospect.The latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxThe latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: larry the cat no10 cat cabinet cats
story: But what is the Whitehall moggys role  Lets take a look at this charismatic beauty, who has seen off two Prime Ministers.Larry the Cat took up his position as Chief Mouser of Number  Downing Street in February  - a year after the Camerons moved in.The  year old tabby is the first cat at No to be given the official title of Chief Mouser.As such, his day-to-day duties include finding a solution to the mouse occupancy of the house.Larry says this is still in tactical planning stage, despite being in the job for over eight years.He has been criticised for not doing his job with the Evening Standard writing about the feckless cats of Whitehall.Larry took the criticism in his stride tweeting: Outrageous slur on our good names we WILL take this laying down...The Prime Ministerial moggy is practically part of the furniture at No, with paps regularly snapping him lounging in the sunshine.Larrys slavesare the Civil Servants in the Cabinet Office.They keep a voluntary kitty to buy his food and have looked after the cat for almost eight years now.His official Government page says he spends his day greeting guests to the house, inspecting security defences and testing antique furniture for napping quality.Larry has stayed in his post longer than the last two Prime Ministers.His Twitter page @Numbercat states hes been in position longer than the leader of any UK political party.He was brought to Downing Street by David Cameron in  from Battersea Dogs and Cats home.Cameron left his post in  after the Brexit referendum - leaving Larry looking for a new roomie.Theresa May then moved in, and in a  interview with the Sunday Times, she said she was very happy to see Larry.She did note there were parts of Number  where Larry rules the roost and things between the two got a bit awkward when he had to be tactically removed from outside Number  before May gave her resignation speech.The Chief Mouser is now showing Boris Johnson the ropes - and making sure he doesnt try and sit in his favourite chair.Larry is a prolic tweeter and on May  announced he was standing to become the next PM.He tweeted: I am announcing that I’m standing to become the next Prime Minister. If Boris Johnson is running, then people deserve a serious candidate too... #LarryForPM #YesWeCatAt the same time he put out an ad for a new butler tweeting: WANTED: New Butler. Ability to sort out Brexit desirable, but generosity with cat treats, combed hair and reluctance to use first name essential... Applications to L T Cat,  Downing Street, London.Unfortunately his name was missed off the ballot papers and Larry failed to be elected - but he still has the most important job of keeping the current PM in order.Larry is not the only Cabinet cat - there are four others with vital roles.From bitter rival Palmerston to the only female, Evie, heres more about the highly-ranked pusses.Palmerston works at the Foreign and Commonwealth Office in Whitehall.In  it was reported he had killed  mice since arriving from Battersea Dogs and Cats Home in  - beating Larrys haul of around .In July , his profile took a e after he slaughtered a defenceless duckling.He is also known to scrap with No cat Larry - often coming out on top.Palmerston can be followed on Twitter @DiploMog.Gladstone was put in charge of the Treasury in .The black tom, who likes to wear a bow tie, is a former stray adopted from Battersea Cats and Dogs Home.He runs #GladdersYoga from his Twitter account @TreasuryMog every Wednesday.He caused a frenzy in Whitehall in September  after going missing - but the black moggy was soon back in his rightful place.Evie was rehomed from the Celia Hammond Trust with her son Ossie and lives in the Cabinet Office.She is the only female feline among the Whitehall mogs.Evie is named after Dame Evelyn Sharp - the first ever female Civil Service Permanent Secretary.In April , Evie was promoted to the face of the Governments Equalities Unit.Ossie is Evies son and was rescued, along with his mum, from the Celia Hammond Trust.Ossie is named after Sir Edward Osmotherly - author of the rules followed by civil servants in giving evidence to select committees.His job is to keep the four floors of the Cabinet Office in Whitehall rodent free.A Cabinet Office insider told The Sun the mother and son pair had been specically chosen to avoid fights with the Whitehall tomcats.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: avoid publicity paul hollywood ask oscar winning judi dench
story: All the drama in his le — the latest being dumped by girlfriend Summer Monteys-Fullam after asking her to sign a laughably self-important “gagging order” — is entirely of his own making.Yet, in an Instagram post richer than triple chocolate mousse, he seemingly blames her for the media attention they attract. He also adds that: “I prefer a quiet le away from the day job.” And the band played Believe It If You Like.To recap: Paul is a master baker who caught a lucky break after being booked to appear on what became TV juggernaut The Great British Bake Off.Back then he was happily married to we Alex and, outside of an occasional media interview to plug the show, his home le never made the headlines.A bit of work and no play made Paul a dull boy when it came to clickbait. Then he had a fling with fellow TV chef Marcela Valladolid and all hell broke loose.Sex sells. It always has. So does scandal, and cheating on your we with a younger woman fits firmly into both categories.When the fling ended, the admirably forgiving Alex took Paul back, but the marriage faltered again and he took up with a -year-old barmaid with a fondness for miniskirts and crop tops.What’s not to love for the hundreds of “paparazzo”who make a living from how many times their photo gets viewed online It’s not rocket science, is it  Earlier this year I spotted Judi Dench out supermarket shopping.Yes, that Judi Dench. Dame of the British Empire. Oscar winner. Recipient of more awards than Mr Hollywood’s had hot buns.And favoured guest of chatshow host Graham Norton. But there she was, browsing the aisles and totally unbothered by anyone.Why  Well, firstly, she wasn’t wilfully drawing attention to herself by radiating self-importance. And secondly, while she’s paid to be dramatic on screen, her le outside of it is anything but.Meaning that, in everyday le, her showbiz currency — the aforementioned “clickbait” — is, depending on how you view such things, blissfully low.But , say, she decided to dump her conservationist partner David Mills for a young barman from her local pub, a photo of her low-key shopping trip would be front-page news. Simple really.Aside from the marvellous Ms Dench, there are oodles of A- listers who live non-famous lives, popping to the supermarket or going for a low-key dinner — for example, not The Ivy et al — with loved ones.Occasionally, they might be spotted and photographed, but they just keep their head down and ignore it, accepting that it’s a small price to pay for the myriad other benefits fame brings.NDAsare now commonly used by celebrities to ensure the silence of, say, a nanny who will be privy to what happens behind closed doors — and that’s perhaps understandable.But asking a lover to sign on the dotted line when you’ve already been together two years is saying, in so many words: “I don’t trust you, but I want to carry on sleeping with you.”Who can blame Summer for telling him to stick it where the sun don’t shine Famous US basketball coach and mentor, John Wooden , once said: “Talent is God given Be humble. Fame is man-given Be grateful. Conceit is self-given Be careful.”Wise words that Mr Hollywoodwould do well to heed.WHATEVER you think of Boris Johnson’s politics, it can’t be denied that he’s working his King Ashurbanipal socks offas our new PM.Hospitals, factories, flood-hit towns – you name it, he’s popping up there to put a smile on everyone’s face and reassure them that everything is under control.He’s the frontman while the rest of the bandare putting in the hours at the studio, hopefully producing the hits. Time will tell.But suffice to say, he’s already shaping up to be the UK’s cheerleader – a feat the more reserved and aloof Theresa May never quite managed.WHEN asked about children, Prince Harry replied that he and we Meghan might have “two, maximum”.Fair enough, I thought. After all, she’s  now and,she’s lucky, Mother Nature might let her conceive one more before her womb shuts shop.But no, it seems the royal couple’s decision is to do with population growth, despite experts saying that, globally, the birthrate is shrinking and the real issue is how long we’re all living.So unless he’s planning to pack Granny off to Dignitas, there’s not much he can do about it. But I digress.Regarding royal babies and, in particular, Harry and Meghan’s sensitivity around their firstborn’s privacy, perhaps they should copy his cousin Zara.She and husband Mike Tindall have two daughters, Mia, five, and Lena, one. There’s no showboating or churlishness, they just give their daughters as normal a le as possible via picnics, getting muddy, painting faces and rough and tumble – as seen in thisdelightful photo of mischievous Mia hitching a ride on Dad’s back.They occasionally get photographed, but clearly accept that it’s just one of those things and don’t let it bother them. A parenting template to be admired, whoever you are.THE author Alex Elle once said: “I am very cautious of people whose actions don’t match their words.”In which case, let’s hope she wasn’t invited to the recent Google Camp party in Sicily which,you’re one of the self-regarding A-listers in attendance, was a high-minded gathering to discuss the issue of climate change.Or to the rest of us – a boondoggle for entitled fools. How  to describe an event attended by  of some of the world’s richest people who arrived on eco-unfriendly private jets and luxury yachts Oh, the unacknowledged irony. Meanwhile, Leona Lewis and ious other celebrities, who advocate gun control, happily took a shilling or three to attend the Austria-based party of Gaston Glock – one of the world’s most famous gun makers.But back to Google Camp where – and I can’t quite believe I’m writing this – residents and hotel guests near the archaeological site of Selinunte were told by police to avoid looking out of their windows to protect the privacy of the invited A-listers dining al fresco.The same slebs, one assumes, who regularly virtue signal their moral credentials by advocating a world without borders, where everyone should be treated the same . . . yada yada. If hypocrisy was a movie, they’d all be winning Oscars.SCHOOLBOY Jay Hughes, , was talking to a friend outside a chicken shop in South London when a van pulled up and three men armed with machetes jumped out.His friend ran off and escaped but Jay stood in the shop doorway, where -year-old Nyron Jean-Baptiste stabbed him before boasting, “I got one”, and leaving the scene.Jean-Baptiste has now been jailed for “le” – whatever that means these days – while poor Jay’s distraught mother Cindy has been condemned to a letime of painful loss.Another devastated mother, Linda Burke-Monerville, spoke last month about sending her remaining children back to Nigeria for safety after losing three of her sons to violent crime in the UK.What on earth is happening to this country  Entire communities feel they have been abandoned by the police while criminal gangs rule by fear – and no one in power seems to know what to do about it.New Home Secretary Priti Patel said this week that she is resolutely focused on restoring law and order to our streets via extra police officers with greater powers.Talk is cheap – particularly when uttered by the majority of politicians. title: whaley bridge residents can return to their homes after six nights away as dam is now safe
story: More than , residents had been evacuated from the Derbyshire town since Thursday as there were fears the dam wall could collapse following heavy rain, although a small number refused to leave their homes.The immediate danger posted to Whaley Bridge has now passed, police said.This is despite the fact the Met Office has issued a yellow weather warning covering much of England, including the Derbyshire town, on Friday and Saturday.Police said a safe water level at the reservoir had been reached after around  per cent of the reservoirs capacity had been pumped out.Derbyshire Police Deputy Chief Constable Rachel Swann said: The hard work and dedication to achieve this has been quite simply incredible.At the forefront of our thoughts are the communities affected by this incident who have been steadfast in the face of the peril that lay behind that dam wall.The danger posed by the millions of tonnes of water, which would have destroyed homes and livelihoods, could not be underestimated.She said work will now be carried out to ascertain the damage caused to the dam wall and what actions are required for the future.Prime Minister Boris Johnson tweeted: So pleased to hear that Whaley Bridge residents, who have shown such spirit and patience, are being allowed back into their homes.I want to thank the volunteers, emergency services, Armed Forces and all who responded with such professionalism and dedication.One resident who has ed, John Lomas, said: Its great to be back home. title: girl seriously burned primark nail glue
story: Little Lilly Worsfold, , was engulfed in a toxic cloud after the p adhesive made contact with the cotton-and-Lycra garment.Primark has launched an urgent investigation into the product after Lilly’s mum Louise posted a shocking video of the dramatic chemical reaction.Nursery manager Louise, , said: “I allowed Lilly to buy some pink plastic nails and a bottle of nail glue from Primark as a summer holiday treat.“She’s used them before - usually she sticks them on and they fall off a few days later.“But on this occasion she spilt a tiny amount of the glue on her leggings and they suddenly started smoking. I’ve never seen anything like it.“Lilly was screaming in agony. I pulled her leggings off as quickly as I could. They were red-hot and starting to stick to her skin.“I rushed her to hospital and they sent us to a specialist burns unit. Now they’re saying she may have to have skin grafts.“As a mother I feel partly responsible for letting her have the nails, but they’re clearly marketed to children and she bought them herself without any questions being asked.“Primark needs to take this product off the shelves immediately before another child is hurt - maybe even more seriously.”Louise, of Farnborough, Hants, added: “Lilly is a very responsible girl, I wouldn’t let her use nail glue otherwise.“I always thought the worst that could happen with nail glue was that you could temporarily stick your fingers together - not that it would ignite your clothing and cause chemical burns.“This is a terrible start to the summer holidays. Lilly can’t go swimming or to the beach and has to keep her legs elevated as much as possible. She’s also facing the prospect of surgery.“On top of that, she’s terried of starting a new secondary school in September with horrible scars all over her legs.”Lilly spent £ of her pocket money on a set of pink plastic nails and p on a bottle of brush-on nail glue from Primark on Saturday.Both bore the chain’s “P.S.” beauty brand marketed at girls and young women.Lilly started applying the nails in the back of the car on the way home. But after spilling a bit of the glue on her £ “Pink Soda” leggings from JD Sports, they started emitting noxious smoke.Her sister Poppy, eight, and three-year-old brother Hugo complained their eyes were stinging as the poisonous cloud filled the car.Louise pulled over immediately and removed Lilly’s leggings, swabbing the burned areas with wet tissues before driving to nearby St Peter’s Hospital, Chertsey.They assessed the injuries and referred Lilly to a specialist burns unit in East Grinstead, West Sussex.Doctors conducted tests which showed the burns were quite deep, and may require skin grafts.Louise and husband Peter, , complained to Primark and they asked them to send in the glue for testing.A Primark spokesman said: “We take the safety of our customers and the quality of our products very seriously. title: ross kemp docu kids machete fashion
story: In it, he speaks to gang members and community workers who are trying to stem the tide of bloodshed on Britain’s streets. He tells us what he discovered . . .It’s a Friday night and we are trying to hand in a machete and a samurai sword at a police station — but we are turned away.I’ve joined campaigner Faron Paul, who runs a one-man kne amnesty, offering shopping vouchers to peoplethey hand in their weapons to him.Faron, , came up with his unique way to try to reduce kne crime on the streets of North London, where he lives, after he was stabbed himself.People contact him on social media and arrange to drop off the blades. He collects up to  knives a day before handing them over to police.Faron, who dubs himself a “Daddy by day and a vigilante by night”, was given the two blades that day. Yet when we arrive at South Harrow police station, there’s a problem.There are no police officers there. And while the station did have a kne amnesty bin, it was rather unhelpfully taped shut. Evenit hadn’t been, the blades we had were far too big to fit.A duty public access officer we spoke to wasn’t in a position to take the weapons and told Faron to take them to Wembley police station.For me, this was a ludicrous suggestion.This was a Friday night and anything could have happened.It wasn’t until I stepped in and pointed out it would be safer for him to take the knives than for us to drive around with them that he was convinced.And it was the third police station we’d tried that evening. The first, Ilford, had a two-hour wait. The second, Pinner, was shut.Faron was a promising athlete — but as a teen his dream of becoming an Olympic medallist was snatched away from him after he was viciously stabbed in two separate attacks.He told me he contemplated revenge and only changed his mind because of the impact it would have had on his family.He should be commended for what he does. And while I wouldn’t recommend others to follow suit, I know he’s not the only person who feels compelled to take matters into their own hands in the face of the kne crime epidemic that is gripping the UK.Because for three years now our politicians have been so obsessed with Brexit and debating our future they have failed to spot that our future is happening now.Kne crime has surged to the highest levels since records began in .In England and Wales,  people lost their lives by a kne or sharp instrument in the year leading up to March , according to official figures.There has been a  per cent increase in the number of victims aged  to . That’s a massive hike in young people getting stabbed on our streets. And every day last year around three people aged ten to  were admitted to AE with kne wounds.Despite what people might think, it’s not just a problem in London. Kne crime is growing fastest outside the capital.We need to start getting the message across that it’s not just affecting inner-city kids in London, as tonight’s programme shows with a look at the problems in the North.These chilling statistics are what led me to investigate the UK’s kne crime epidemic for the penultimate episode of my latest ITV documentary series — because whatever is being done is not working. And we have to look at the reasons why our young people pick up a kne.During filming I spoke to one young man who viewed the side holster for his machete in the same way as a new pair of trainers — a fashion accessory.Gang members I spoke to all have one thing in common, revealing they were all excluded from mainstream school before having a chance to finish full-time education. They were all sent to pupil referral units.It’s been suggested that, because schools are under so much pressure from Ofsted to be high-achieving, they push out the troublesome children who could bring down the rest of the class.One of the young gang members said to me: “You tell meit makes sense to put a bunch of bad kids from one area that already have problems into an environment with other bad kids from another area. That doesn’t make sense.”Of course it doesn’t. It’s obvious when you think about it, isn’t it And while some of these pupil referral units succeed, many are seen as training academies for crime gangs.When our new Prime Minister Boris Johnson pledged to hire up to , police officers by this time next year, it was given a warm welcome.The recruitment drive begins next month, with the ambitious aim of having , officers in place within three years.It’s a good thing, don’t get me wrong. But how long will it take to train these officers And how long, once in place, will it take them to build trust in the community The young men I met told me the same thing time and time again: “Show me a better way.” Faron is a great example of how social media can be used for good. But I’ve seen first-hand how it plays a negative part in the rise of kne crime in this country and how easily name-calling online can result in the death of a young person.Not only has it taken away a le and has an impact on the victim’s family, it also has a massive impact on the perpetrator and their family.It’s cancelling out lives, essentially over name-calling on social media.During filming, most of the people I met felt like they were facing or fighting kne crime alone — from the young person carrying a kne for protection to someone in the local community having to take matters into their own hands because they feel there is no other option.Yesterday, counter terror chief Neil Basu said improved social mobility in the UK could do more to stop extremism than “policing and state security” combined.He added that policies which go towards better social mobility and more education are much more likely to drive down violence.And what he says about terrorism could just as well apply to kne crime.There is certainly no quick fix to this problem. We need to stop young people picking up knives, and this will involve giving them options rather than just excluding them. We need to look at the part played by social media in the escalation of violence.We need to look at the connection between poverty levels and kne crime and to send the message that carrying a kne is not cool or fashionable.And, of course, we need more police officers who have the trust of the communities they police.And, more importantly, government needs to convince the people living on the front line of kne crime that there is genuine help out there. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: no need to ditch traditional puds
story: More than a third of young diners have never eaten a spotted dick and a quarter have never had a slice of flan, according to a study.What’s more, a fth of Brits aged  to  have never tried Eton mess, banoffee pie or rhubarb crumble — and one in six last ate jelly and ice cream TEN years ago.Traditional puds celebrate seasonal ingredients and are a pleasure to make. title: uk holds the best cards brexit
story: We were warned about this before the referendum and have been told almost continuously for the past three years a British recession is just around the corner. Figures released on Monday showed a rebound in confidence in the dominant services sector.Of the large Eurozone countries, only Spain is currently outgrowing us — but Spain is still recovering after a very deep recession from which it emerged in . In common with Italy, the Spanish economy is still smaller than it was before the - banking crisis.Not that you will hear any of this from Remainers. Every time a car factory is earmarked for closure or a steelworks runs into problems, we hear no end of people saying, “We told you so”.MOST READ IN OPINION" data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   dk-comp-rod-liddle-boris-v.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentROD LIDDLE Boris has been playing hardball with the EU from the outset… only May had too " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   NINTCHDBPICT.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentTHE SUN SAYS No one is more clueless than Remain diehards who have plotted to stop Brexit " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   Tm-comp-Desserts.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentALEX JAMES Millennials are dodging traditional British puds but heres why they shouldnt " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   NINTCHDBPICT.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentTHE SUN SAYS Hypocritical Remainer MPs are wrong to insist BoJo plays by the rules " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   PMCOMPP.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" JANE MOORE You CAN avoid all publicity, Paul Hollywood — just ask Oscar-winning Judi Dench All bad news in the UK economy is automatically attributed to Brexit — on the BBC, especially. What we don’t hear is that manufacturing industries, especially cars and steel, are suffering the same problems across Europe.Germany’s car industry is still reeling from the scandal of Volkswagen cheating in emissions tests by installing software to detect when a car was in test mode.On top of that comes the proposed switch from petrol and diesel to electric cars. Many motorists — myself included — have put off buying new vehicles because we don’t know what to get.We have been told new petrol and diesel cars will be banned from  and worry they might be taxed out of existence well before then. Yet electric cars are still prohibitively expensive and can’t travel nearly far enough between charges.As for the steel industry, all across Europe it is struggling to compete with cheap competition from China — especially since the trade war with the US forced Chinese exporters to search for new markets away from America.Of course,we end up with a No-Deal Brexit and tarfs are imposed on imports and exports between Britain and the EU, it will cause some disruption to trade. But it is wrong to assume Britain will come off worse. In truth, EU exporters have more to lose. Britain runs a huge trade deficit with the EU.In  we exported £billion worth of goods and services to other EU countries and imported £billion from them — a trade gap of £billion. Moreover, EU exports to Britain are concentrated in products that attract relatively high tarfs.Cars, for example, attract an EU import tarf of ten per cent. If Britain chooses to impose that levy in reverse after Brexit, it will cause further mayhem in the German car industry.We also have a high deficit in food — which under EU rules attracts average tarfs of  per cent. For dairy products, the average EU import tarf is  per cent. If our Government decides to impose this on imports from the EU, it will mean the end of quite a few French cheese producers.Of course, the EU can avoid damaging these export industries by agreeing to a trade deal with the UK — one that doesn’t include the hated Irish backstop.Nearly half of Irish food exports go to the UK. Irish exports to other EU countries would be deeply affected as so many rely on UK roads. If there are delays at ports, traffic between Ireland and the Continent will suffer twice over — once crossing the Irish Sea then crossing the English Channel.EU leaders want to punish Britain for voting to leave their sacred project. They fear thatBritain is seen to do well, other countries will want to leave. But playing hardball with Britain will do deep harm to their own export industries.Does German chancellor Angela Merkel want to suffer the wrath of her country’s car makers  Does French president Emmanuel Macron wish to anger winemakers already struggling with an economic downturn at home A hard Brexit could cost Denmark as much as one per cent in lost gross domestic product. Their former economy minister Simon Emil Ammitzboll calls Brexit “the most visible threat to the Danish economy”.Holland and Belgium calculate similar falls will hit their economies, with the Dutch losing ten billion euros by . In Spain, wages for unskilled youths are lower than they were in the late s. Youth unemployment is a huge problem. Even qualied youths face a lower annual salary than their counterparts a decade ago.The alternative to all this is for the EU to swallow a bit of pride and agree to keep free trade flowing, perhaps via a temporary deal while long-term arrangements are negotiated.It won’t take much. Just remove the backstop — really just an underhand way of trying to keep Britain in the straitjacket of EU regulations and trade barriers — and some kind of withdrawal agreement would almost certainly make it through the Commons.If not, then yes, British industry will suffer in some ways from No Deal. But the Eurozone economies already lagging behind will take the bigger hit.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris playing hardball eu from outset
story: First, he’s making the threat of No Deal serious. With Theresa May, it never was. Brussels knew she didn’t even want to leave, never mind with No Deal.And whenever No Deal was threatened there would always be some helpful soul in her Cabinet to say . . . “That will never happen.”  People such as the treacherous Philip Hammond.Not any more. Second, he’s shaking up the civil service a bit.  It was civil servants who did most of the negotiating — and they are all wildly pro Remain.But with Boris’s adviser Dominic Cummings wielding the stick they might just be a little more amenable than before.Third — he’s realised that the bloody Northern Ireland backstop was never anywhere near so serious an impediment as the Remainersclaimed.And fourth, and maybe most importantly, he’s leading the country with a sense of optimism and chutzpah.Of course it’s Boris, so he may well do something totally bonkers and wreck the process. But so far he’s got everything right.He hasn’t got long to sort out a deal, the days are counting down. But my guess is that he WILL get one.The EU likes to talk a hard game but it usually budges in the end. It is desperate to avoid No Deal.Andit doesn’t budge — fine. A bumpy road for a few weeks and we’ll be OK, better off than ever. And free. The big threat to Brexit is not the EU — it’s our Parliament, once again.The Labour Party has ditched all semblance of principle and is now for a second referendum.Worse, Boris has a majority of only one. That’s not his fault — blame Theresa May for calling an election two years ago.It looks to me thatMagic Grandpa Jeremy Corbyn calls a vote of no confidence, he will probably win.Labour is already cosying up to the Scottish Nationalists and saying they wouldn’t mind a second referendum on independence.There is now nothing Labour wouldn’t do to gain power. Destroy the union and scupper Brexit — Magic Grandpa doesn’t care.Butthis whole thing ends with Labour des- troying Brexit, the party will never be trusted again.Oh sure, it will still get the votes from the metropolitan, middle-class lefties. But its working-class base will desert it, for good.So the message for Magic Grandpa is very clear. Win your vote of confidence, lose your voters. He’s not the brightest of men, but I do hope he grasps this.And Boris  Keep straight ahead. Play as hardball as possible with Brussels, knowing they want a deal. Strike as many deals with the likes of the USA and Canada as possible.And remind Brussels thatwe walk away without a deal, they don’t get a single penny from us. That should help to concentrate their minds for a while.This has been revealed in a new report by researchers with too much time on their hands. What these men want, I think, is the best of both worlds.I used to have a girlfriend who spent all day long sitting on the roof of the shed. Then she’d dart out into the road after a thrush. She was great.Had a little bell around her neck. And did her business in a small tray by the back door.A WOMAN in East London said nasty things to someone taking part in a gay Pride march. She was wearing a niqab, so the lefties didn’t get too cross.Still, it is at last beginning to dawn on the woke liberals that the more fervently Muslim a person may be, the less likely it is that he or she will take kindly to people who have a knack for interior design and enjoy watching Mamma Mia!.This has put them in a bit of a quandary. Much as have those largely Muslim protests outside schools in the Midlands which insist on teaching kids how wonderful gay relationships might be.The same sort of quandary that affects feminists, who are not entirely convinced that a ft chap with a todger and a beard who wishes to be called “Loretta” in the name of gender freedom actually is a woman.This is the thing with identity politics, protected characteristics and so on. Tug gently on one of its threads and the whole thing begins to unravel like a pink mohair jumper knitted by an imbecile. HERE’S some consol­ation for you cricket fans, in despair at our Ashes defeat. Steve Smith, the man who did most of the damage, is at least HALF English.He’s got an English mum and has dual nationality.He used to play cricket for a team in Sevenoaks, in Kent.So what we should do is ide his run total down the middle – we get half, the Aussies get half. That means we won the first Test. Fair dinkum Sometimes I think that one day I’ll be the only person left in the country paying tax.And I’ll get rung up by the Inland Revenue. “Sorry, Liddle, we need to fire off a few missiles to scare the Iranians. We’ll take it out of your next payment.”Thing is,people aren’t paying tax, or aren’t married to someone paying tax, should they have the vote THE way to pose for your Instagram shots this summer is to stand with your elbows in the air.Here is someone doing exactly that.And so everywhere you go this August, you will find young women doing a passable imitation of a cormorant.Those scented pine-tree things could obscure your view of oncoming traffic, apparently.Have to say, I wouldn’t mindthey were banned altogether. Especially that really sickly one that’s supposed to smell of coconut.Here’s a tip, mini-cab drivers. If you want your car to smell nice for passengers, maybe take a shower once in a while HANGING an air freshener from your car rear-view mirror could land you a fine.APPARENTLY,you stare hard at a seagull in a menacing fashion it will be too scared to nick your packet of chips.This is the new advice from the experts. I’ve known it all along. Stare hard at the bird asit’s just spilt your pint, or tried to chat up your girlfriend.And also add in a bit of abuse and threats for good measure. “You f***ing want some, you yellow-beaked t***er “I’ll cut you open like a tin of peaches, Sunshine.” Always works, until the Old Bill turn up. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: kfc diner served raw chicken staff ignore complaint
story: The woman bought the chicken from a branch in the city of Townsville in Queensland, Australia last Friday.But she says when she opened the meal, she discovered the chicken was raw, and immediately called the store.The unhappy customer later wrote about the incident on Facebook, accompanying a post with pictures of the uncooked food, the Daily Mail reported.The girl on the phone seemed interested and asked me to email photos through and they would call back, she wrote.No call back yet and no response.The social media post sparked a backlash from previous customers, with many pledging to boycott the chain.This is why I will never eat it! This happens all the time, one wrote.That is sooo bad I don’t think I want to eat it again, another said.Never eating chicken again, a third pledged.Ive gone off their burgers. Every time the chicken doesnt taste right, a final user wrote.

title: cambodia man trapped mountain rocks
story: Cops said Sum Bora, , slipped into the tiny crevice on Sunday while trying to retrieve his flashlight, which had fallen in the small rocky hollow.The man had been collecting bat droppings in the Chakry mountain jungle in the northwestern province of Battambang when he fell.His worried family began searching when he didntafter three days, Cambodias Fresh News reported.Sum’s brother found him and alerted authorities to his location in the mountains.About  rescue workers carefully freed the trapped man by destroying bits of the rock that had pinned him in an effort that took about  hours, police spokesman Sareth Visen said.The -year-old man was freed at about pm on Wednesday, looking extremely weak, and was taken to a provincial hospital, the police official said.The rescue was spearheaded by specialists from Rapid Rescue Company , which is connected to Prime Minister Hun Sens elite military bodyguard brigade.The group also was prominent in rescue efforts when a seven-story building collapsed in June in the southern city of Sihanoukville, killing  people.Cambodia is one of the poorest countries in the world, with % of its . million people living in poverty, according to a U.N. Development Program report last year.Bat droppings, or guano, is used as fertilizer and sold for supplementary income by poor farmers, who sometimes try to attract bats to their property.The Cambodian mans plight evokes memories of the film  Hours starring James Franco.This film is based on the real-le story of climber Aron Ralston who found himself trapped alone in a canyon in Utah and had to perform DIY surgery to free himself.Ralston had been climbing the narrow Bluejohn Canyon alone when a dislodged boulder fell on to his right arm, trapping him against a rock.He was entombed in the wilderness for five days and eventually cut off his own arm so he could escape.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ryanair strike 2019 dates update august pilot
story: Heres everything we know about why pilots are walking out - and when.Strikes are set to be held from .am on August  until .pm on August .The walkout will continue from .am on September  until .pm on September .The first strike on August  coincides with a planned strike by BA staff over pay disputes at Heathrow.A union statement said the strike was the result of decades of Ryanair refusing to deal with unions.Members of the British Airline Pilots Associationvoted by - to back a campaign of action on a  per cent turnout.Balpa said the dispute revolves around pensions, loss of license insurance, maternity benefits, allowances and a fair, transparent and consistent pay structure.Brian Strutton, Balpas general secretary, said: We have had no formal offer from Ryanair and it is imperative that we resolve this dispute urgently to avoid strike action.No pilot wants to spoil the publics travel plans but at the moment it seems we have no choice.The strikes come after Ryanair boss Michael OLeary said  jobs were at risk at the airline because there was an excess number of pilots and cabin crew.The airline said its UK pilots agreed a  per cent salary increase, with Senior Captains earning up to £,, which it said is more than competitors.Ryanair said in a statement that it was disappointed with the strike threat.They said the industrial action does not have the support of the majority of Ryanairs UK pilots.Ryanair added in a letter to Balpa: At this dficult time for UK pilots facing base cuts and closures, Balpa should be working with Ryanair to save UK pilot jobs, not endanger them through ill-timed and ill-judged disruption of our customers’ travel plans, just  weeks before the threat of a no-deal Brexit.But the airline might not pay outits out of their control, for example, due to bad weather or strikes.If your flight is delayed by three hours or more and you were flying to or from a European airport, or with an EU-based airline such as Ryanair or British Airways then you can claim compensation up to £for short-haul flights and £ € for mid-haul flights and £for long-haul flights.You can find out more here.The strike only affects British pilots with Ryanair, meaning flights using crews based in France, Spain, etc wont change.Estimates by The Independent indicate that , travellers are expected to fly on British-crewed flights, with up to , seats still to be sold on those departures.Based on previous Ryanair pilot strikes, around a third to a half of UK-crewed flights would expect to be cancelled.The airline tends to inform passengers on flights that are to set to be cancelled two or three days ahead.It is not recommended to cancel now as its possible that the strikes wont go ahead at all.Both the airline and union say they dont want the strikes to happen.Making your own travel arrangements would also stop the airline from making alternative arrangements for your travel.Heres our guide on how to claim compensationyour flight has been delayed or cancelled.

title: madeline mccanns parents british tourists posters
story: The official Find Maddie Campaign website, endorsed by Kate and Gerry, says: Thank you for being by our side as we continue to search for Madeleine.”At the start of the holiday getaway last month they urged travellers to take downloaded pictures, luggage tags and car stickers, stating: “It could be the poster that brings Madeleine home.”The fresh appeal came weeks after Britain’s top cop admitted she had no ideathe case would ever be solved.Met Police commissioner Cressida Dick revealed she could not saydetectives would discover what happened to Maddie despite the y inquiry which has cost the taxpayer £.million.The investigation, codenamed Operation Grange, failed to unearth any signicant clues since it started in May .But officers have been given an extra £, to keep the search for Madeleine going until the end of March next year.The Maddie Facebook page has been bombarded with messages from well wishers saying they had downloaded posters to take abroad to display at key points including airports, hotel lobbies, eateries and shopping malls.The site, which is viewed by thousands across the globe, gives thanks to supporters under the heading “For as long as it takes” - a pledge Kate and Gerry made on the th anniversary of their daughter’s abduction in May.Jane Knape vowed: We are ing to Barbados on th August so will take a few with us - anything we can do to help.”Members of the public have written messages of hope, which a source close to Maddie’s parents said had “really buoyed them up.Steve Metcalfe posted: “Prayers to the family. I want to do more, as a police officer and a parent this disappearance has deeply affected me.”Linda Law wrote: “She will be found, I feel sure, and I believe it will be her eye that gives her away.”Deb Donner added: Sending mental hugs your way and positive energy for finding your beautul girl. When your hope seems to fail and you feel lost, know we hold you up with our hope.”To try and keep Madeleines disappearance in the global spotlight as the summer holidays start, there are printed pictures to choose from in  dferent languages.Dferent images of Madeleine are displayed on the poster, including the photos of her as a three-year-old wearing a sunhat and a scarlet dress and the last age progression photo of her with the message: Have you seen this little girl  and Dont give up on me.Madeleine vanished days before her fourth birthday in May  after parents Kate and Gerry left their children in their Praia da Luz holiday apartment in Portugal’s Algarve.Former GP Kate and heart doctor Gerry, both , from Rothley, in Leicestershire, believe their daughter could still be alive. She would now be aged .The Facebook page states: “Fortunately, there are many cases of abducted children being found and ed to their families - even after long periods of time.We are extremely grateful to everyone for downloading and displaying a poster – it could be the poster that brings Madeleine home.Home Office chiefs revealed cash for the investigation is provided through Special Grant funding which is usually available to police forces when they face signicant or exceptional costs.Not one piece of forensic evidence linked to the little girl has been found since she vanished.And despite trawling through thousands of tip-offs and potential sightings, police have not confirmed that a single one was her.

title: jeremy corbyn labour unfit government
story: But Labour are still lumbered with their dismal, discredited chief.Even as Jeremy Corbyn sinks deeper in the mire of unpopularity, his party makes no real attempt to dump him.Instead of taking action, Corbyn’s detractors just carp and criticise from the sidelines.Last week’s poor result in the Brecon and Radnorshire by-election, where the Labour candidate gained just five per cent of the vote, led to a new wave of condemnation.Former Northern Ireland Secretary Lord Hain said that Labours performance at Brecon had been truly dreadful, yet our current leadership carries on regardless towards disaster.Even more savage was another former Cabinet Minister Alan Johnson, one of the most respected Labour moderates, who said that practically anyone would be better in the job.Jeremy Corbyn is not just pious and sanctimonious, he’s useless at leading, which is why he has people around him to do his shoelaces and pull his strings, claimed Johnson.As a former Labour activist who spent a decade working alongside Corbyn in his Islington North constituency, I agree with everything Johnson says.Having observed him at close quarters during the years when he was a backbench rebel, I now find the idea of Corbyn as Prime Minister both laughable and terrying.Profoundly unfit for the highest office, he is a toxic ideological extremist without a clue about how to govern Britain.Having poisoned his own party, he would wreck our country toohe came near to power.But what makes me despair is the timidity of sensible Labour folk, who regard Corbyn with contempt yet are still willing to march under his banner.They proclaim that they think he is a disaster, but they allow him to remain in place.This pathetic ineffectuality was captured by Yvette Cooper, widely regarded as possible alternative leader, who bleated to the BBC at the weekend that there is a real concern we don’t look like enough of a broad church at the moment.What a gross understatement.In fact, the Labour Party is in the grip of hardline, quasi-Marxist, anti-Semitic personality cult.But apart from wringing their hands, the likes of Ms Cooper do nothing about it.If Labour is to have a future, the moderates have to get off their knees and start to challenge Corbyn properly.They should be inspired by the words of the great former leader Hugh Gaitskell, a passionate centrist, who famously told the  conference — where the left had prevailed — that he would fight, fight and fight again to bring back sanity and honesty and dignity to the party I love.The moderates need that kind of resolution today, but they show precious little sign of it.They are not only cowardly, but also hypocritical.They send their angry tweets and whine to the broadcasters, but, by campaigning for Labour, they are still working for Corbyn to be Prime Minister.If, as appears likely, a General Election is called soon, the so-called moderates will all be out canvassing in their constituencies for theof a Corbyn-led Government.That reality makes all their denunciations of him completely meaningless.Effectively, the moderates are Corbyn enablers and agents of his extremism.Rather than serve as doormats, they should take a lesson from the Tories, who have long been ruthless about dumping their leaders.Neville Chamberlain, Anthony Eden, Ted Heath, Iain Duncan-Smith, and even Margaret Thatcher were all clinically dispatched once they were deemed to be ineffective or unpopular.The same ruthlessness with personnel could be seen in the way Boris Johnson reconstructed his Cabinet last month as he sacked  ministers in his night of the blond knives, including even the Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt.In contrast, Labour has always been pathetically soft about butchery.In the whole of the party’s -year history, only one leader has ever been forced out against his will and that, ironically, was Tony Blair, by far Labour’s greatest election winner.All the rest chose when to go, even the poor ones like Neil Kinnock, Michael Foot and the s pacist George Lansbury.Today, there are plenty of steps that the moderates could take to crank up the pressure on Corbyn.They could push for another vote of no confidence in him. They could resign the Labour whip in the Commons. They could boycott his appearances at Prime Ministers Questions and other statements.But, as Labour slides towards catastrophe, they have done none of this.What explains their inaction  Part of the answer is fear of the Corbyn machine, especially his supporters’ powerful pressure group Momentum, which is notorious for its intolerance.In fact, though there has been a recent decline in Labour membership, Corbyn backers still make the majority of activists.Any Labour MP who speaks out against Corbyn therefore risks deselection. For the sake of their Parliamentary careers, most of them keep quiet.But there are also deeper factors at work.One is mainstream Labour’s horror at any supposed betrayal of the socialist cause.This is partly because Labour is such a tribal movement, as shown in the ferocious anger generated in  by Ramsay MacDonald’s decision to break with the party by forming a National Government with the despised Tories.Since then treachery is regarded as the greatest sin, far worse than incompetence or unpopularity.This trait particularly insulates Corbyn, who, for all his spectacular failings, is still regarded by the majority of the membership as an authentic socialist.There is also a deep streak of sentimentality in Labour, which stems from the party’s origins in the trade union movement.In this mindset of supposed compassion, sacking people is what the bosses do, not the workers.When the nondescript Clement Attlee was surprisingly elected Labour leader in , supporters of his rival Herbert Morrison tried to comfort him by saying Attlee’s spell at the top would be short-lived.Morrison was having none of it.The party, he said, was sentimental and having once made a man leader, would stick to him.He was right. Attlee was still in post  years later.Sentimentality explains why so many anti-leadership plots are botched.I saw this for myself working as a Labour researcher at Westminster in the late s and early s, when there were hidden manoeuvres against Kinnock.But they all came to nothing because the plotters lacked the determination to finish the job.The same was true during Gordon Brown’s woeful premiership, when conspirators abandoned the battle when the moment came to strike.More interested in dogma than office, the Labour party lacks the unsparing instinct for power that infuses the Tories, which helps to explain why the Conservatives have been in Government for twice as long. Since  , the Tories have been in office for  years and Labour for just .The absence of hard ambition means that socialists are willing to put up with a dud like Corbyn, while they mouth their slogans and wave the red flag.The wilderness is their ideological comfort zone – and Corbyn will ensure they remain there.

title: brussels chiefs want showdown with boris but order him to keep the backstop first if he wants better deal before october 31
story: The European Commission said the Withdrawal Agreement was “not up for negotiation” in a statement today.Commission spokeswoman Mina Andreeva told a news briefing in Brussels: “So far it...remains unchanged - this position that the Withdrawal Agreement is not up for negotiation but we are open to talk about the political declaration.“And of course we are willing to talk and engage with Prime Minister Johnson.”The PM has so far refused to hold talks with EU chiefs and will not compromise on his stance against Theresa May’s hated deal.He has previously warned thatthe EU dont budge on getting rid of the backstop, it will be their choice to push Britain out of the bloc without an agreement by October .The backstop, which would come into playa future trading arrangement falls short of keeping the border open, has been the main stumbling block on Brexit negotiations.However, Andreeva said it was not the Commission’s “business” to play a “blame game”.MOST READ IN NEWS" data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   Tm-comp-Teacher-Mc-Devvo-New-v.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" ExclusiveBAD RAP Primary teacher sacked after being outed as foul-mouthed YouTube rapper MC Devvo " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   CRUISE-SHIP-BYE-GIF.g stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CRUISE YOU LOSE Cruise ship crewman waves giant hand as late passengers watch it sail off " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   AD-COMPOSITE-Jordan-Lindsey.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" TORN APART Woman mauled by sharks tried to swim with one arm -
