title: waterfoot park residents take council task proposed construction development
story: Derry City and Strabane District Councilhas pledged to engage fully with a group of residents in the Waterside after they accused the local authority of failing to fulfil their obligations in relation to their objections to a potential building development in their district.In July last year, residents of Waterfoot Park in the city lodged a formal objection to plans for a housing development in the area seeking to construct four semi-detached houses, two detached houses and six, two-bedroomed apartments.The Waterfoot Park residents objected to the proposed development on several grounds which included the potential impact of the construction project on existing properties at the site and that the planning application had not indicated accurate separation and height dferences between the proposed new project and the existing homes.A statement from the Waterfoot Park Residents Objectors Committee to the Derry News said: “The proposed dwellings are three stories in height on ground over two metres higher than the existing houses with restricted separation distances between both.“The layout would result in loss of privacy, natural light, sunlight and overbearing dominance, creating a sense of being hemmed in for us existing residents living adjacent to the boundary line.“Our concerns are also for the natural habitat of wildle species and the overall vast vegetation and trees. No details were provided on how existing vegetation will be retained and no bioersity checklist was provided.”The residents also employed planning consultant Lee Kennedy, who told the Council of his concerns that some demolition work to existing buildings on the proposed development site had already taken place, prior to planning approval and that trees had been felled along the rear boundary of the site close to the homes of the objectors.A spokesperson for the Waterfoot residents said: “Mr Kennedy went onto state that residents have expressed genuine fears about a threat to the remaining vegetation on the application site.“He reminded Council that they hold a duty of care to work in the public interest and offer protection to the remaining mature trees, by the serving of a Provisional Tree Preservation Orderunder the  Planning Act.”Mr Kennedy confirmed to the Derry News that he had submitted a request for a TPO from the Council, but “no action had been taken.”However, the Waterfoot Park residents say their fears were heightened again earlier this month when a team of workers appeared on the proposed development site and began to cut down more trees.A spokesperson for the residents told the Derry News: “On Friday, July  at .am the neighbours were woken with the sound of several power saws and saw a full team of tree cutters on site behind them.googletag.cmd.push .addSize.addSize.buildslot  googletag.defineSlot.defineSizeMapping.setTargeting.setTargeting.setTargeting.addServicegoogletag.displaygoogletag.pubads.refresh“Within an hour they had created absolute mayhem on the site, with trees felled all around and they were left when they fell. The ground and houses nearby vibrated and caused house alarms to go off.“Some neighbours felt very intimidated, shocked and panicked with the suddenness, noise level and by the time of the morning it happened. The residents are up in arms. It should never have been allowed to happen as Council was made aware last year about their responsibility of a duty of care to work in the public interest. The residents feel unsupported to date in their endeavours to the Council.”Addressing the residents’ concerns, a spokesperson for Derry City and Strabane District Council said that: “During the processing of the application,  objections have been received to the proposed development.“Correspondence to the Planning Department from Planning Consultant, Mr Lee Kennedy acting on behalf of the objectors, was received on August ,  and raised concerns regarding the trees on the site, and a request for a Provisional Tree Preservation Orderto be served on the site.“These concerns were raised with the Planning Department’s Tree Preservation Officer on September ,  who advised on September , that in his professional opinion, a TPO was not appropriate for this site given the nature, type and scale of trees.”On April  this year, Planning Department officials met with objectors at the city’s Council offices, where again, the Tree Preservation Officer advised that a TPO was considered but was unnecessary when assessed against the criteria required for a TPO.The Council spokesperson continued: “The site was further inspected by planning officers on June ,  and officers met with objectors on site.“More recently, the case officer wrote to the agent and the applicant on June ,  to advise that further information was required. Amongst other things requested, the case officer advised that a tree survey of the site was required, a landscaping plan to show existing trees and vegetation to be retained and additional planting to be shown and a bioersity checklist was to be submitted to advise on any existing ecology on the site.“The agent confirmed in correspondence dated, July  that a Phase  habitat survey was instructed to be carried out as well as a tree survey and would be submitted in due course.”However, the Council spokesperson added: “The Planning Department were made aware by an objector by email on July ,  that eight trees along the boundary of the site adjacent to properties in Waterfoot Park had been felled on July  at .am.“Council takes its obligations in respect of these matters seriously and has undertaken an appropriate course of action to ensure that the opinions of residents are and will be fully considered in the processing of the planning application.”CAPTION: Residents of Waterfoot Park have accused the Council of failing to provide a duty of care in relation to a proposed building development.

title: Charity Beer and Bubbles 5k run in Finnebrogue
story: M B McGRADY  Co Chartered Accountants is setting the pace this September with the launch of the Beer and Bubbles k run in a bid to raise money for Air Ambulance NI.Open to competitors of all ages and experiences, the race will take place on Thursday, September , at Finnebrogue Woods, nestled on the outskirts of Downpatrick.This is the first k race to take place at the idyllic venue, with the route mapped out so runners take in the stunning woodland and finish close to the lakeside, where they will be able to soak up the atmosphere while enjoying a glass of local beer or prosecco.The event follows on from last yearrsquos successful M B Grady  Co Ultimate Aqua Challenge,.Conaill McGrady, director of M B McGrady  Co, said: ldquoWe are delighted to be supporting Air Ambulance NI for a second year and helping to contribute to maintaining the vital work that they do. Last year we held the first Aqua Challenge and this year we wanted to do another first ndash so Bubbles and Beer came to fruition.ldquoJust like last year we are encouraging not only clients, co-workers and friends to take part, but also those within the local community who are looking for a fun challenge.Mr McGrady paid tribute to Ed Lindsay and his team at Finnebrogue Woods, which he described as a stunning location.He added: ldquoWe are working with local event management company,  Extreme, to ensure this is an enjoyable and memorable experience for all involved and encourage people of all abilities to come down and enjoy a walk or run.Air Ambulance NI Area Fundraising Manager, Grace Williams, said: ldquoWe are very proud that M B McGrady  Co are continuing to support Air Ambulance NI with another unique, fun, family event.ldquoItrsquos set to be a great evening and we would love to get as many people as possible taking part, enjoying the evening and raising money for our charity.She added: The Helicopter Emergency Medical Serviceis tasked on average at least once a day. To ensure this is sustained, we need to raise pound million each year so public support is crucial. By taking part yoursquoll be making a lesaving dference and helping to raise vital funds for Air Ambulance NI.Air Ambulance NI works in partnership with the Northern Ireland Ambulance Service to provide the Helicopter Emergency Medical Service for Northern Ireland and is the local accountancy firmrsquos charity partner of choice for the second year.M B McGrady  Co Chartered Accounts has three offices situated in Downpatrick, Belfast and Newtownards.The race starts at .pm, with registration open from .pm. To sign up visit www.mbmcgrady.eventbrite or call   ..prettyPhoto

title: Classy Corey lifts silver at World Youth Savate event
story: AN Annacloy teenager has just ed home from from the Savate World Youth Championships in Budapest with a silver medal.Thirteen year-old Corey McCullough, a member of Joe Ferrisrsquo Bryansford Academy, who was at the championships as part of the Irish team, narrowly missed out on gold to a Russian fighter he had beaten earlier in the competition.Savate, a French combat sport that uses the hands and feet as weapons, combining elements of English boxing with graceful kicking techniques, has been an integral part of Coreyrsquos le for the past three years mdash although he has been kick boxing since he was six.Corey fought in the kg category and he has now set his sights on being part of the Ireland team that will travel to the European Championships next year.A pupil at St Malachyrsquos High School, Castlewellan, Corey is indebted to his coaches Joseph Ferris and Martin OrsquoMalley. He is also extremely grateful to sponsor Philip Polly, from CosyRoof and Brian McElroy, of Premier Chiropractic Centre, Downpatrick..prettyPhoto

title: Downpatrick FC host Golf Day
story: THE clubrsquos annual Golf Day was held last Friday at St Patrickrsquos Golf Club, with over  players playing on a course which was in pristine condition and in glorious sunshine.Unfortunately, nobody was able to take advantage of the playing conditions and get a hole in one at the par three th and secure pound, in cash which was kindly sponsored by Murphyrsquos Bar and Restaurant.The winners were: membersrsquo first prize, Michael Baggley nd Conor McMenamin rd, Mark Fitzsimons. The non-membersrsquo winners were: st Andy Baggley and nd Joe McMahon. The closest to the pin on th was Mark Murphy.The club would like to thank Murphyrsquos Bar  Restaurant for sponsoring the hole-in-one, thank you to Docrsquos Fish  Chip Shops for sponsoring the BBQ and to all our hole sponsors: Niall Powderly and family, Sean McMahon, Connollyrsquos Spar, BMD Contracts, Molloyrsquos Fish  Chip Shop, Bayview Killough Holiday Home, McGreevyrsquos Butchers, Eugene Milligan, MC Dental Laboratory, ALPS, United Mortgages, JRrsquos of Castlewellan, Matts Gardening Service and The : Diet, Down, Lecale  Ards. We would also like to say a special thanks to St Patrickrsquos Golf Club captain Patrick Totton, the members of St Patrickrsquos Golf Club, club professional Charlie Bell and the excellent greenkeepers for allowing us to use their excellent facility.Downpatrick begin their league campaign in Division A tomorrow night with an away fixture against Orangefield OB at Cregagh Sports Club in Belfast. This match kicks off at .pm. Then on Tuesday night they travel to play Rosario YC at Ulidia Playing Fields, this match kicks off at .pm.Over the next few weeks all our teams will be ing to training in preparation for the upcoming season, keep an eye on our Social Media pages for more information..prettyPhoto

title: Fred seals win in added time
story: A FREDDIE OrsquoConnor point in added time gave Bright a stirring victory over second-placed St Paulrsquos at Pairc Mac Con Midhe on Friday night.The game was played in perfect conditions with a slight sea breeze being the only element for players to contend with.Bright took possession from the throw-in and ultimately controlled the early part of the game. They opened the scoring through Gareth George and he added a free to give the visitors an early cushion.Indeed, Bright had plenty more chances to add to this score, but were wasteful in their shot selection. The Holywood men finally woke up and a tidy score from Connor McAnespie after  minutes opened their account.Bright again replied with a fine score from Marc Burke before Martin Cox opened his account for Holywood with a point after  minutes. Barry Kilkey levelled the contest three minutes later from close range and Freddie OrsquoConnor scored for Bright to edge them ahead again.Foolish tackling and unnecessary frees were costing St Paulrsquos in the game and helped Bright dominate the play In the first half.The gamersquos opening goal, however, swung the play towards the Holywood men again. Fantastic work from Seaacuten Tucker around the middle of the park and his long ball into the danger area found Marty Cox in space.Cox caught the ball in mid-air, landed and turned in one motion before smashing the ball past Michael Ferrand, who had no chance. The sizable crowd roared with delight and momentum was now with St Paulrsquos as Tucker added another score from play.Once again, however, ill discipline and poor tackling would cost St Paulrsquos. Paddy Falls high tackle left George with a handy free to cut the deficit before Tucker added a free from m out on the left.George added the final score of the half for Bright leaving St Paulrsquos two points clear at the half-time whistle - to -.Bright again took the early initiative at the start of the second half and a point by Rian Tempany set the early tone. A big talking point came at six minutes into the second half when referee John McMullan sent off two players, one from each team after an altercation at a break downThe next few scores were to and fro with Tucker scoring three points and George replying in kind, aided by Tempany. The game was tied at - to - drawing at  when St Paulrsquosadded their second goal in the th minute.Fine work from Daniel Eastwood and Cox set up Tucker who danced around two Bright defenders before slotting the ball home from  metres. The home crowd were again in raptures, expecting St Paulrsquos to see the game out.However, game management has been a big problem this season for the Holywood men, given the average age of the team is  it is perhaps understandable that experience to see games out is just not there yet.St Paulrsquos tried to slow the game down, but with about  minutes still to be played, it was far too early for that. Bright caught St Paulrsquos in possession on numerous occasionsand turned the ball over for score after score.George was a constant threat and punished each mistake by the Holywood men with a score. Ably assisted by Freddie OrsquoConnor, the pair hauled the St Paulrsquos lead in until it was all square by the th minute.They again caught St Paulrsquos out and OrsquoConnor scored the winning point in the st minute.St Paulrsquos: Craig McKenna, Owen Loughran, Conor McPeake, Ryan Loughran, Ruairi Collins, Paddy Falls, Michael Collins , Gerard Walls, Patrick Eastwood, Martin Cox , Seaacuten Tucker , Daniel Eastwood, Barry Kilkey , Conor McAnespie . Subs: Daacuteire McGrattan. Ryan Hughes, Conleth Rooney, Rodney Adams, Colm OrsquoConnor, Matthew Crozier, Josh Johnston, Fintan Eastwood, Euan Morrow.Bright: Michael Farrand, Niall Byrne, Barry Mageean, Noel Travers, Corey Ranaghan, Nicholas OrsquoConnor, Freddie OrsquoConnor , Cailean Toner, Seamas Tumelty, Jack McLaughlin, Declan Trainor , Gareth George , Marc Burke , Kevin Groves , Owen McEvoy. Subs: Martin Murphy, Oran Tumelty, Christopher Byrne, James Hanna, Joseph Farrand, Rian Tempany , Declan Quinn, Jude McCrissican.St Paulrsquos -Bright -ACFL DIVISION .prettyPhoto

title: French Lamorlaye visitors are twinning group guests
story: NEWRY, Mourne and Down Council chairman Charlie Casey welcomed a party of visitors from Lamorlaye in France recently.The visit was organised in association with the Rowallane and Slieve Croob Community Twinning Group with guests staying in Ballynahinch and hosted by local families in Rowallane and Slieve Croob districts.Their stay followed a visit by the Deputy Mayor of Lamorlaye, Madame Yasmine Chani, earlier this year.The Lamorlaye community twinning partnership was set up primarily with Ballynahinch, Drumaness and the Spa in .Over the years, many school groups and members from the local community have participated in cultural, linguistic, equine, sporting and business exchanges and organised joint trips to the European Parliament in Strasbourg, the European Commission in Brussels, to Slovenia, the Czech Republic and the south of Ireland.Over the three days, the French visitors were treated to a busy schedule which included a visit to the historic Down Cathedral, the Saint Patrick Centre and Down County Museum.The group was taken on a tour of the County Down coastline to see Ardglass, St Johnrsquos Point Lighthouse, Killough, Newcastle and Slieve Croob. The group was also taken on a walking tour of Montalto Estate in Ballynahinch.The Rowallane and Slieve Croob Community Twinning Group also organised a charity garden party to enable the visitors to meet their friends from the Rowallane and Slieve Croob areas in an informal setting, which included the councilrsquos deputy chairman, Terry Andrews, and concluded with a rousing performance of La Marseillaise.Cllr Casey welcomed the French delegation with a reception at the Millbrook Lodge Hotel, Ballynahinch.He said: ldquoThe main objectives of the three-year plan of the twinning arrangement are to organise healthy activities and events, bring generations together in experiencing two fabulous cultures and share our heritage with partners from all over the south of Ireland, west of Scotland, Galacia in Spain, Wales, the Isle of Man and Brittany.ldquoAs part of our councilrsquos strategic objectives, we are striving to become a premier tourism destination on the island of Ireland, and empowering and improving the capacity of our communities.He told the visitors: ldquoThese objectives could not have been achieved without the continued support we have received from initiatives such as twinning arrangements.ldquoFrom visiting the area and investing in our local businesses, to bringing dferent cultural experiences to the citizens of our district through ious projects, I would like to thank you.He added: ldquoOur mission as a council is to lead and serve a district that is prosperous, healthy and sustainable.ldquoI am pleased to have you all here to celebrate the  years of this twinning arrangement. We can be proud of how far we have come to achieving this, in building a united, culturally erse community together..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C July 31%2C 1979
story: DOWNPATRICK mdash Downpatrick is believed to have been put under the microscope for possible inclusion in the itinerary for the Popersquos three-day visit to Ireland.The programme for the Popersquos visit has already been drawn up and dispatched to Rome, but no one is willing to confirm that Downpatrick is on the list.The Primate, Cardinal Thomas OrsquoFiaich, was unavailable for comment, but a spokesman for him said that he could not comment on the matter. He did, however, admit that the itinerary has been sent to Rome.Venues for the Popersquos visit are pure speculation and certainly newspapers are free to speculate, he added.It is understood that Downpatrick was one of the three venues north of the border suggested by the committee of  bishops, headed by Cardinal OrsquoFiaich, when they met last week.The decision on whether the Pope will include Northern Ireland in his tour will be taken in Rome, but it is believed that alternative venues in the Republic have been suggestedthe Pope decides not to cross the border.The choice of Downpatrick mdash with its strong historical links with Christianity and St Patrick mdash is understood to have been a move to give the Pope the opportunity to see as many people as possible.It is also thought that Armagh mdash the ecclesiastical headquarters of the Roman Catholic Church in Ireland mdash and Londonderry were studied as possible venues for a visit.Until the programme is finalised, the only places certain to be included in the itinerary are Dublin and the Marian Shrine at Knock, County Mayo.Dr Joseph Maguire, Parish Priest of Downpatrick, said that he personally had not been contacted about any visit from Pope John Paul II, but he admitted that Downpatrick would have been one of the first places to think of.ldquoWe would be delighted to be so honoured with a visit from the Holy Father and he would be most welcome he said.KILLYLEAGH mdash A one-day token strike by production workers closed the Killyleagh Mill yesterday.Around  workers walked out, seeking a wages increase. It is understood that negotiations are going on around the table to try and thrash out a compromise.The token strike, which is also hitting other linen firms in the province, is expected to be prolonged unless the workers receive what they are seeking.TYRELLA mdash An extensive redevelopment of Tyrella Beach has been earmarked in a draft report which proposes to bring most of the beach area into public ownership.The report prepared by a group of consultant engineers working for the Down District Council has been described as ldquohighly practical and has already been given council approval.No cost estimates have yet been carried out on the scheme, but senior council officials are already preparing the way to convince the Department of Commerce and the Northern Ireland Tourist board to supply the necessary money.If the plan goes ahead the biggest change in the appearance of Tyrella will be the absence of cars on the beach area. Two special zones will be developed for car parking on either side of the beach and a park for upwards of  cars will be provided in the centre, off the beach area.Under no circumstances, however, will cars be allowed to drive up and down the beach area and the council is expected to appoint full-time beach inspectors to supervise parking during the summer season.The private entrances presently used by beach-goers will be blocked off and two new public driveways will be constructed. It is thought that charges for cars to the beach will be scrapped.Other developments at the beach will include the provision of new toilet blocks and the construction of - self-catering holiday homes for renting.NEWCASTLE mdash A new peal of six church bells will ring out over Newcastle this year. They will be installed in St Johnrsquos Parish Church, which will be  years old in .Dr Noel Warren, the rector, says the parishioners are looking forward with tremendous interest to hearing the first peal of new bells to be installed in any church in Ireland for many years. The installation scheme will cost pound,, of which pound, has already been raised.The only special event to raise money has been a coffee party by Mr and Mrs Gerald Annesley. It produced about pound,.The church has always been under the patronage of the Annesley family who paid a great deal of its construction cost.STRANGFORD mdash The Roads Division has confirmed the report in the Recorder last week that the Cranglersquos Rock Corner, near Strangford, is to be re-aligned mdash and they have announced a firm starting date.A spokesman admitted this week that work had already started but he explained that this was only preliminary to the actual scheme to re-align the three bends, and was being carried out with the consent of local landowners.The spokesman also admitted that the scheme had been brought forward from its original starting date of - because of pressure from district councillors and local people.ARDGLASS mdash The death took place on Monday of one of the most popular persons in the area, William Curran, of Ardglass. Sailor Bill , as he was known, was born in Blaneystown and was a nephew of that other great Sheepland character, Willrsquos Billy Curran.In , Sailor joined the Royal Navy and his -year hitch took him through the first World War and some time in the West Indies.When he retired from the navy he became restless at home and decided he would give the minefields in Scotland a try.After his first day down in Ayrshire pit he was very disillusioned and decided not tobut he was prevailed upon to give it at least another day. He did and this day turned into  years.CROSSGAR mdash Crossgar man David McClurg continued on his winning ways with his Jersey cows at the County Antrim Agricultural Show at Antrim on Saturday.Having won the championship at Omagh and Castlewellan Shows, he made it a hat-trick of successes.Not only did he win the Granger Cup for the champion Jersey, but also the Lever Cup for the champion heer, the Lawther Cup for the best group and the first winner of the Eagle Cup for the Jersey with the best udder.KILLOUGH mdash A nephew of the late Canon Napier, of Killough, has been conferred the honour of Knighthood of St Gregory by Pope John Paul II. Dr S Napier, who has been in practice in Derby, for the last  years, received the honour recently.TEMPLE mdash Banbridgersquos Noel Hudson became the latest name to enter the Temple  record books when he won two races on Saturday.But it was Dromara Destroyer Ray McCullough, who caught the eye of the locals as he won the cc class to chalk up his th first place over the Temple course since first racing there  years ago.Many doubted McCulloughrsquos ability to win at the temple on Saturday. Since his spectacular fallin the North West last year, he hasnrsquot been registering victories as often mdash but they reckoned without his love for the Temple course and watched eagerly as he ran up another success.GAA mdash Loughinisland for so long known as the lsquogypsiesrsquo of East Down football, as far as playing pitches is concerned, have at last come of age.On Sunday their new ground and permanent home will be officially opened by Paddy McFlynn, the president of the GAA.The Loughinisland club was founded at the start of the present century and in their  years they have, at ious times, played on pitches throughout theand breadth of the parish..prettyPhoto

title: Great turnout for multi cultural event in Ballynahinch
story: HUNDREDS of people attended the multi-cultural family friendly celebration at The Square in Ballynahinch on Saturday.The Connecting Cultures Event was held to help promote community cohesion and encourage acceptance and understanding of other cultures.In addition to music from all over the world, there were dancers entertaining the crowd, face painting, an exotic petting farm, stilt walkers, circus skills and cuisine from ious parts of the world.The African drumming proved particularly popular, with people of all ages keen to take part. Representatives from the Menrsquos Shed and the PSNI were also in attendance.Also attending the event was Newry, Mourne and Down Council deputy chairman Terry Andrews.He said: ldquoThe council is delighted to be part of this exciting event to celebrate local and ethnic ersity.Increasingly we live in a more erse community and it is important that we learn from each other and create safe, vibrant communities for the future.ldquoTodayrsquos event allows new residents to meet their neighbours, begin friendships, sample new tastes and experiences, and also gain a sense of pride in their inclusive community. I look forward to similar events taking place in the future.Cllr Andrews added: ldquoIt was clear from the feedback received during the event that everyone thoroughly enjoyed the whole experience, which had something for everyone irrespective of age or culture.The Connecting Cultures event was run in association with Choice Housing, Rowallane and Slieve Croob District Electoral Areas, The Executive Office, Together Building United Communities, Housing for all and the Northern Ireland Housing Executive.Sharon Hunt, Community Support Officer for Choice Housing, said: ldquoBuilding strong and resilient communities is just as important to Choice as building great homes.ldquoThatrsquos why, through the Together Building a United Community Strategy, we are delighted to host this wonderful festival, which has been an enormous success.ldquoWe would like to thank all our partners, tenants and community members who took part in the festival. We have been overwhelmed by the support..prettyPhoto

title: Make a Wish is the winner
story: THE th Kevin Gorman Memorial Cup drew a massive crowd to Meadowvale, Drumaness, on Saturday.The annual fundraiser for the Make a Wish Foundation is run by Jackie and Shane Gorman mdash Kevinrsquos mother and brother mdash in memory of Kevin who tragically lost his le attempting to save a PSNI colleague in .Sixteen youth teams played in a tournament, before the main match which saw Drumaness Mills beating the PSNI - for the honour of the memorial cup in its last year.There was a number of attractions for the children throughout the family fun day, and the day concluded with music throughout the evening in the clubhouse.Jackie and Shane would like to thank everyone for their support throughout the years, including their loyal volunteers, sponsors, and Drumaness Mills for the use of their facilities.ldquoIt would be impossible to thank every inidual, but you know who you are and we extend our warmest and heartfelt thanks, Jackie said.ldquoIt was indeed fitting that the Mills won the cup in its final year, and this saw Kevinrsquos two daughters, Shannyn and Abi, present the cup to his brother, Shane..prettyPhoto

title: Meeting on blueprint future for Ardglass
story: A PUBLIC meeting which may help shape a blueprint for the economic future of Ardglass was held last week.Members of the Ardglass Development Association and other local groups and organisations attended the meeting in the Gerry OrsquoShea Centre, which could well unleash the villagersquos economic potential.Debate focused mainly on what Ardglass had to offer its thousands of international tourists, as well as job creation and boosting the local economy.The two-hour long meeting was addressed by consultants from Blue Zebra, a strategic planning agency.One of the consultants told the meeting that it was fundamentally important for Ardglass to ldquohave one voice, which would ensure more successful grant applications.Local councillor Dermot Curran attended the meeting and said he was very encouraged by the ideas that were shared.He said: ldquoWe discussed the many attributes Ardglass had to offer. We were pleased at the steady stream of international tourists coming to visit.ldquoMany were in an agreement that we needed to capitalise more on our visitors including the busloads that come from the United States Europe, and Japan who come to play got and that we could help to extend their stay and ensure it is an enjoyable trip.ldquoAt the moment many wives who come up with their golfing husbands go shopping in Belfast but we could do more to keep them here.Cllr Curran said there was a need for more tourist accommodation in the village. At present there are ten bed and breakfast establishments and a small hotel.He also said St Patrickrsquos Trail could be further developed to encourage more walkers to come to the area.ldquoWe need to encourage more people to get involved in offering accommodation and we need to look at creating more jobs in the area especially within the catering and fishing industries, he continued.A report containing proposals discussed at the meeting will be drawn up by Blue Zebra and presented at the next public meeting in the village at the end of this month..prettyPhoto

title: New sports field opens at Ardglass
story: A pound, sports facility has been officially opened in Ardglass.The state-of-the-art Meadows playing fields got the ribbon cutting treatment yesterday, heralding a new era for the area.Among those in attendance was Newry, Mourne and Down Council chairman Charlie Casey, who officially opened the playing fieldsAlso present were South Down MP Chris Hazzard and local councillors Dermot Curran, Cadogan Enright, Gareth Sharvin, Oonagh Hanlon.Cllr Curran, who lobbied for the scheme over many years, said the park will be a terric boost forlocal families for many generations to come.He said the playing fields, complete with a professional-level changing room area and a pitch that can accommodate both soccer and junior Gaelic football, was a first class facility.There is also a kick-a-bout area which can be used for other sporting events.Cllr Curran said he wished to pay tribute to Newry Mourne and Down Council director Michael Lipsett and his team for their input.ldquoThe total cost was pound, which had been set aside by the old Down Council for the development, which I ensured would be transferred to the new council for that purpose only, he remarked.ldquoI understand it has taken a long time to reach the completion stage and there have been a few ups and downs along the way, especially when the design incorporated a six feet perimeter fence which proved problematic.                                                           ldquoHowever, all these problems were overcome and we were able to move on. Today, we have a modern facility for the people of Ardglass and surrounding area to enjoy..prettyPhoto

title: Saintfield director scoops accolades for 2:40 to London
story: HErsquoS done it again. A Saintfield writer and director has received more plaudits at a major British film festival.Gavin Irvine scooped Best Film and Best Comedy awards at the Brighton Rocks Film Festival for his hit comedy film, : to London.Gavin beat off stf competition with other entries in the comedy category alone.He said afterwards: ldquoI was shell-shocked when I heard my name being called out. I just canrsquot believe the run of good fortune Irsquom receiving.ldquoComedy is the hardest genre to be successful in. Probably becausecomedy is so subjective. You either get it or you donrsquot.The movie : to London has been described as a ldquoa wry Beckettian homage to the great British spy thriller but with carrots and beards.ldquoI suppose because the film is totally original, while it takes its influences from British Ealing comedy and the classic comedy era, it goes further with the idea of espionage and the spy thrillers mixed with some extremely dry wit, he remarked.ldquoThe comedy has been doing the short film festival circuit in London this year and the feedback has been amazing.ldquoMost notably, critics say the film is very original. For me, as a film-maker, lsquoploughing your own furrowrsquo is what itrsquos all about.ldquoI donrsquot want to be an imitator. I want to lead but, of course, this is extremely hard to do.Gavin is no stranger to the industryrsquos red carpet events with : to London having won the Audience Award at the Making Waves Film Festival in Portsmouth in  and Best Short Film at the German International Film Festival and the Brazil International Film Festival. It also received the Special Jury Award at the Canadian Independent Film Festival.Gavin, who fell into filming making over  years ago and was winning awards within two years. Earlier this year he scooped Best Short Screenplay for his latest film, Lunch, and the Rising Star Award for his debut music video, Rattling My Chains, at the Portuguese International Festival..prettyPhoto

title: Ursula’s special day at Spa
story: SPA lady president Ursula Kelly hosted the clubrsquos third major event of the season on Friday with her Lady Presidentrsquos Day competition mdash played in glorious sunshine on a course which continues to attract so much favourable comment.Once again it was Carol Shields who topped the leaderboard, continuing her outstanding season long success with a fantastic score of  points.Pam Trohear was also on top form, taking the gross prize while Gwyneth Cordner was second and Elaine Beattie was third.Philip Shields was the leading man in the nine-hole menrsquos competition after facing fierce competition from Pat Savage, who was second, and Graham Mills, who finished third.The lady president said that for her it had been ldquoa very special day and after congratulating all the winners, thanked everyone involved in the preparation and presentation of the event and all who had competed.She paid tribute to the ldquohard work and efficiency of handicap secretary Gillian Earls, ladysecretary Catherine McEvoy, lady captain LizGeddes and the ladiesrsquo committee along with Marian Armstrong and Heather Edgar in the office, juvenile convenor Gwyneth Cordner, professional Gary Wardlow, the bar, catering and grounds staff.ldquoI want to thank my family and extended family for the support they have given me over the past two years and especially my long suffering husband Jimmy. title: Volunteer Malachy stepping down
story: THE annual Downpatrick street collection in aid of the Meningitis Research Foundation will take place on Saturday August .Eighty-year-old Malachy Doran and his dedicated group of volunteers will take to the streets of Downpatrick once again to raise much-needed funds to defeat the disease, fund new research and campaign for new vaccines, better treatment and greater awareness and support.This will be the last collection for Malachy, who has worked tirelessly as an organiser and co-ordinator for over  years and the Meningitis.Research Foundation would like to pay tribute to him and his family for their long-standing support.MRF is a cause particularly close to their hearts as it affected their grandson, Conor, when he was a baby.It was an extremely distressing time for the family as Conor was critically ill, but thankfully he made a great recovery. However, they remain aware that not every family was as lucky as they were.Malachy would particularly like to pay tribute to all his collectors over the years and the people of Downpatrick for supporting his annual street collections. Last year an incredible  volunteers were involved in the street collection.To date, well over pound, has been raised from the Downpatrick area. Such has been Malachyrsquos dedication that on March  this year he was presented with an award from Newry, Mourne and Down Council for Outstanding Fundraising in aid of MRF.MRF fundraising and support officer Paula Donaghy said: ldquoOn behalf of MRF, I would like to thank Malachy, his family and all his collectors for their commitment and dedication.ldquoMalachy is an amazing man who has quietly organised and coordinated the collection for over  years and we are exceedingly grateful for his support. As a charity, we rely on the generosity and support of the local community to sustain our vital work.ldquoAll money raised will help us to continue to fund cutting-edge research into the prevention, detection and treatment of the disease, raise important awareness of the symptoms and support all those who have been affected.ldquoMalachy has been a fantastic support to the organisation and it is his hope that as he retires someone from the area will take over the coordination of the Annual Street Collection and carry on his legacy.Mrs Donaghy said meningitis was a deadly disease which acts fast and is hard to detect. It can happen to anyone, of any age, at any time.ldquoThe vision at MRF is of a world free from meningitis and septicaemia, she continued. ldquoA world where effective vaccinations can protect everyone. ldquoA world where people who do get the diseases get the most effective diagnosis and treatments possible. A world where people affected, and their families, have the best support and information.ldquoIn , around , people died of meningitis and it is estimated that over one million survived who now have to live with the after effects, such as limb loss or brain injury.ldquoFunds raised through street collections such as this one in Downpatrick go a long way towards helping MRF achieve these goals.Anyone who would like volunteer for the collection in Downpatrick on August  is asked to contact Dominic Doran on  , email dominicdoran@yahoo.For more information on meningitis and septicaemia, or the work of MRF, visit www.meningitis.org or telephone   ..prettyPhoto

title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: The Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. The cows visit the robots on average . times per day averaging  litres per day with some exceeding litres. But when he arrived, to his dismay he found that the interview with the then taoiseach Jack Lynch had been turned into a press conference and he had largely wasted his time..ev-modals .modal.in .modal-dialog .photo-article-notier-default .ev-widget .photo-article-notier-default .photo-article-notier-default .ev-widget p @media.photo-article-notier-default .ev-widget p #jp .main-content .ev-widget#sticky-footer .sticky-footer-banner .photo-article-sticky-footer-banner .photo-article-sticky-footer-banner p @media@media#sticky-footer .desktop-sticky-footer_text,#sticky-footer .desktop-sticky-footer_button #sticky-footer .fluid-container #sticky-footer .mobile-sticky-footer_button It was Lynch who took the Republic into the EU on the same day as the UK joined in  – arguably Ireland’s single most transformative decision since partition.The outbreak of the Troubles meant that Lynch’s policy towards Northern Ireland defined much of his tenure, and although the current Taoiseach, Leo Varadkar, only took up office two years ago and is only , Brexit is already almost certain to define his time in office.Leo Varadkar speaking to News Letter political editor Sam McBride in Belfast on TuesdayHis robust strategy of insisting that the UK commits to a backstop which treats Northern Ireland dferently to the rest of the UKBritain is to leave the customs union and single market now looks like it could have the unintended consequence of contributing to the UK leaving without any deal at all – a major economic threat to Ireland.Two weeks ago a poll found that a minority of the Irish publicback his Brexit strategy. The stakes are high not just for the Fine Gael leader, but for his nation.Sitting in the modern offices of the de facto Irish embassy in Belfast – the Irish Secretariat on Linenhall Street –Mr Varadkar has misgivings, he doesn’t show them.With relentless message discipline, he repeats the Irish government’s stance, insisting that it will not give up the backstop anda no-deal Brexit happens then it will be London’s choice.Mr Varadkar is a cautious interviewee, choosing words carefully and often appearing to say little beyond what has already been said. Even when asked when he first visited Northern Ireland , there is a sense that he is always thinking politically, delicately selecting his words.Did Northern Ireland at that time feel like an entirely dferent country or society “No. No. It definitely felt dferent, and is dferent, but certainly not foreign. I’ve always liked Belfast as a city and Queen’s in particular as a campus.”No deal Brexit risks cull of , Northern Ireland cattle, reports BBC NewsnightLeo Varadkar interview: We will oppose direct rule for Northern Ireland Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "BELF | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "BELF | Article Teaser"Again, when asked whether British-Irish relations are at their lowest point since the  Belfast Agreement – which seems obvious – he is coy, saying that relations between people in Britain and Ireland are “pretty good”, while “definitely Brexit has strained relations between the two governments ... and has created a very dficult environment for the parties in Northern Ireland”.But on Brexit there are subtle linguistic changes which hint at how the situation is changing. In January, he said that “even in a no-deal, there will not be ato a border”. Now, he implicitly accepts that no-deal will mean that there will be an economic border – although he hopes it can be enforced away from the border itself.However, he is clear that regardless of what happens – deal or no-deal, backstop or no backstop – the movement of people around the island will be unimpeded. Despite some people’s fears that no-deal would mean a border, impeding the movement of people crossing the border to shop, visit relatives or go to school, Mr Varadkar is clear that will not be the case.Highlighting how the UK and the Republic have given firm commitments to retain the common travel area, he says he is “confident” that will continue, along with access to each other’s labour markets, housing, education, welfare and pensions “as though we were citizens of both Britain and Ireland”.“We’ve agreed to keep that in place – so as long as the British and Irish governments commit to keep that in place, that will stay in place and our commitment to that is absolute and solid. I would hope that down the line the British government doesn’t decide that taking control of our borders means in any way diluting the common travel area – certainly we won’t.”His one caveat to that is that it is impossible to be certain of what “may happen down the line ... a lot of the reasons for the checks during the Troubles were security-related and I would certainly hope that the security situation would not deteriorate”.He stresses that violence at any future border is not inevitable “but I think we would be doing a disservice to our citizens north and southwe didn’t understand that it is a potential outcome”.Last week Arlene Foster – once Mr Varadkar’s opposite number as Stormont tourism minister and from whom he accepted an invitation to attend the Twelfth in Enniskillen seven years ago – accused him of being “very truculent” and refusing to engage in “sensible bilateral” discussions with the UK. She said he “hides behind the apron strings of the EU ... and he won’t speak to those of us who have a very big interest in finding a way forward”.When those comments are put to the taoiseach, he smiles, saying: “Yeah, I heard that and I’m conscious that it was Arlene Foster only last week who was advising me to dial down the rhetoric.“I don’t think in two years as taoiseach and in eight years in the Irish government I’ve ever made a pejorative comment about any unionist politician.”In a time of crisis in Northern Ireland  years ago, Jack Lynch’s solution was simple: “The reunication of the national territory can provide the only permanent solution for the problem.”Although Irish unity is more seriously talked about now than for many years, Mr Varadkar’s responses to questions around unity reveal a reluctance to rapidly move towards such a prospect.Asked whether the classic Irish nationalist idea of unity – an Irish unitary state – is a realistic or achievable prospect in the medium term, he said: “I would really not like to see the Brexit debate becoming a constitutional one. I fear thatyou have a no-deal hard Brexit, that that will arise and I don’t want that to happen ... I would really not like to see this issue of a united Ireland being brought to the fore as a consequence of a hard Brexit.“It’s the kind of thing that I always envisage,it ever would happen, it would happen in a more generational context and would give us time to talk about what that might look like because certainly for me it wouldn’t look like a unitary -county republic, the kind of thing that was envisaged by the founding fathers of the state, those that fought in the GPO – because that could never fully respect or embrace the million people here in the north who are British, who have a unique identity ... that was perhaps one of the flaws of the founding project of my state – that wasn’t properly respected at that time.”When askedhe envisaged the Irish and British governments staying neutral in a border poll or campaigning on either side of the debate, the taoiseach laughed and said: “That’s a good question, actually. I haven’t been asked that one before. I think long before we would ever have a border poll we would have to have a long and meaningful conversation as to what the question really is – we saw that with Brexit people voting on the issue of Brexit without perhaps a proper debate about what Brexit would look like or what Brexit would be.”Leo Varadkar, the gay son of immigrants at the head of a confident and technologically advanced Ireland, is a world away from Jack Lynch, the champion hurler at the helm of agrarian Catholic Ireland. But just as Northern Ireland unexpectedly imposed itself on his Fianna Fáil predecessor, so it is once more threatening to destabilise the southern state.try catch  TrendingN.I. title: view from parliament stephen doughty
story: There is no getting around it we must call the result of the European election what it is ndash a huge wake up call for UK Labour and Welsh Labour.But the vote for those parties whoclearly oppose a reckless Tory No-Deal Brexit and are campaigning for a final say in a public vote, was incredibly strong.The Brexit Party and Faragersquos isive far right politics were not supported by around two-thirds of voters ndash and it is absolutely clear therefore that No Deal was rejected.But the truth is that the country remains ided, and the only way to resolve this is to go back to the British people in a confirmatory referendum.UK Labour must now back this policy clearly, and Irsquom pleased to see senior shadow cabinet members speaking out on this.I therefore also welcome the clarity from Welsh Labourrsquos First Minister Mark Drakeford who said: ldquoFaced with the damage of a hard line Tory Brexit, Welsh Labour believes that the final decision must be made by the public in a referendum."And for the avoidance of any doubt, a Welsh Labour Government would campaign, in such a vote, for Wales to remain in the EU."We will work with any others who seek the same outcome.It is easy to claim to know what the will of the people is ndash but the only way to find out is to actually ask them.This is what the hard line Brexiteers are afraid of.As poor as the European election results were for Labour, the Conservative vote completely collapsed, and their party is in absolute turmoil.With Theresa May announcing that she will depart soon, we are already seeing the posturing of Tory MPs who want to become their partyrsquos new leader and thereforethe Prime Minister.Any new Tory leader must realise two crucial facts: that there is NO majority in Parliament or in the country for a reckless No Deal Brexit ndash as the results of the European elections make clear and the ONLY way to resolve this chaos is to put the issue back to the people, and for the public to story: Their behaviour is intimidating and will not be tolerated in our community. Wersquove had reports of youths consuming alcohol, using nitrous oxide canisters along with reports of damage caused to motor vehicles.Officers are working with British Transport Police to tackle this issue.Alcohol has been confiscated from groups of youths and a number of anti-social behaviour referrals orders have been made.Patrols have increased around the anti-social behaviour hotspots and operations at the train stations and surrounding areas will continue.I would also like to raise awareness of rogue traders in the area.Last week, officers attended to an address after concerns were raised about an elderly woman being asked to pay a large sum of money to have her patio cleaned.No money was exchanged and enquiries are ongoing into this incident.Residents should be wary of anyone who arrives at their property unannounced and uninvited and they should always very callers are who they say they are.We would advise people not to allow cold callers access to their property, to get at least two separate quotes before agreeing to have any work being carried out, to look out for their elderly relatives and neighbours, be vigilant and to contact the police immediatelythey are approached by any suspicious iniduals.If you see something suspicious or have any information related to this activity then call us on  or on appropriate. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. many American Presidents have not been offered a state visit, we didnrsquot have to do it.We can have that governmental and diplomatic contact and we absolutely should be standing alongside America in NATO and in so many other ways - but for Trump the red carpet has been rolled out despite him being so offensive to civilised values.We choose who we honour and I think itrsquos appalling that we are welcoming with such pomp a man who I think represents the very worst of the world ndash and certainly doesnrsquot represent the British and American values that I love.Last Friday I helped to host a group discussion that attempted to bring together all sides of the Brexit debate - despite having lost my voice towards the end of last week!At the event, local people, employers, community leaders and young people ndash from both sides of the Brexit debate ndash gathered to discuss the biggest challenges that face this country.Rather than the endless arguments over whether or not we should leave the EU, the aim was to start thinking about how we can heal the isions in our country and put the focus back on all the other issues that really matter, such as ensuring we tackle crime, invest in our public services and act on global challenges like climate change.That begins with understanding why so many people voted to Leave in  and how we can tackle some of those issues. My own view on moving forward is that a final say Peoplersquos Vote on any Brexit deal is the best option.It was a really positive event, and thank you to all constituents who attended. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... title: penarth developments could lead to  more cars daily
story: The Barry to Cardf Link Road Group has said the number of planning applications already approved in the area - as well as a number still in the pipeline - will have a dramatic impact on traffic.The group has claimed the only alternative would bethe Welsh Government complete the Barry to Cardf link road with access into adjoining communities, saying this would improve access for Wimpy Homes Cog estate, which already has planning permission for  houses, with another  houses also planned.The Welsh Government itself owns the land overlooking the sea at Cosmeston, where  houses are planned.There are a further  houses to be built near Oak Court in Lower Penarth.Rod Harrod, the chairman of the Barry to Cardf Link Road Group, said: ldquoGovernment statistics estimate there are . cars per house so with , houses there could be over , more car journeys daily in the area.With most people travelling back and forth in the same day, conservatively traffic on the Penarth to Sully to Merrie Harrier roadcould rise by around , more trips every day.ldquoThese figures are not scare stories. The current congestion is there to be seen.ldquoAny changes will take at least five years to implement.ldquoEven without the extra  Wimpy homes there are already  new homes built at St Josephs on Sully Road and  planned for Llandough.ldquoThey will all converge on the Merrie Harrier junction.A study carried out in  - before most of the new developments were planned - predicted the junction would be  per cent over capacity by .The new Link Road group has been formed to engage with representatives of all surrounding areas.Cllr Neil Moore, leader of the Vale of Glamorgan Council, said: ldquoThe councilrsquos cabinet recently agreed to consider undertaking further work on the WelTAG Stage  assessment for improving strategic transport in Dinas Powys. Unfortunately, the recent Welsh Government Transport grant funding announcement for   did not make any monies available for this particular project. Therefore my officers are currently investigating whether there are any alternative sources of funding available to complete this Stage  work.Mr Harrod said: ldquoThis should be something for all the people of all the Eastern Vale.ldquoEach area should have its own group.ldquoWersquore asking councillors and officials to consider the domino benefits and detriments of the several routes proposed ndash not just one."He also emphasised that no particular route for a new relief road was preferred, saying: ldquoIt will inevitably require compromise.ldquoBut we want to make sure the final choice will stand firm when the Welsh Government assess the application. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentsOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... title: radio glamorgan studio renamed in honour of penarth volunteer
story: John Wilce worked in hospital radio from  until his death in September last ltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgtyearlt spangtlt spangt" Radio studio renamed in honour of Penarth volunteerThe Radio Glamorgan team based out of University Hospital Wales, at the rededicaltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgttionlt spangtlt spangt" Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentTHE studio at Hospital Radio Glamorgan has been renamed in memory of a dedicated Penarth volunteer.John Wilce joined the station based at the University Hospital of Wales in Cardf in  but sadly passed away after a short illness in September last year.Jamie Pritchard, Radio Glamorgan chairman, said: ldquoSince Johnrsquos passing, we have been thinking of ways of how we could honour him and his legacy at the station for many years to come. The renaming of our on-air studio to ldquoThe John Wilce Studio was a popular choice to recognise his outstanding dedication.ldquoJune  wouldrsquove been Johnrsquos th birthday, so this we felt really was a fitting tribute and a lovely memorial to all those who knew him, as a constant reminder of his contribution to Radio Glamorgan.Mr Wilce regularly presented on Sunday evenings, often dedicating features to listeners. Without fail he played a Beatles track every time he was on air.When Mr Wilce was off-air, he oversaw and maintained broadcast equipment, actively engaged in fundraising and stood as a trustee, assisting with the day-to-day running of the station.Jamie added: ldquoI speak on behalf of everyone at RG to say it was a privilege to know John, not only as a fellow volunteer but as a friend. He always put everyone  first and his patience was beyond words. His music knowledge was phenomenal and the impact he had on everyone he met, not just at Radio Glamorgan has really come to light since his passing.Michelle Fowler, volunteer services manager at Cardf and Vale University Health Board, said: ldquoItrsquos such a wonderful tribute to rename the studio after John. He really made an impact on our wards and with our patients who listened to his shows.ldquoItrsquos such a lovely way to mark not only Johnrsquos birthday but also to mark the contribution he made as a volunteer during Volunteersrsquo Week. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: youngsters celebrate in style as school marks world book day
story: The classes moved around the school and park, stopping at dferent locations to hear dferent storytellers ndash family, governors and friends of the school, many in full costume.Shelley Barrett was dressed as Mole from the Wind in the Willows. She said: ldquoI loved it. The children love being read to and I love doing the voices! I look forward to it every year, choosing the book and costume.Author Elly Grfiths read extracts from her new book lsquoA Girl Called Justicersquo, and shared insights about writing a story.At the end of the day, on Thursday, May , the children and parents were able to buy books from two pop-up book stalls on the playgrounds, organised by Grfin Books.The Albert Road media monitors said: "A big thank you to Mel and her team for helping us and the book stalls proved to be a big hit with everyone."It was a glorious day and the sun truly shone for all the children and adults who participated in this event."World Book Day has really inspired the children to get creative, have a go at writing their own stories and also read new books"Albert Primary School would like to say a big thank you to everybody who helped make the day such an overwhelming success!"On Thursday, May , Albert Primary celebrated World Book Day at school and across the road in Belle Vue Park, Penarth.The classes made their way around the school and Belle Vue Park, stopping at dferent locations to hear stories told by a number of dferent storytellers.The storytellers were made up of parents, governors, grandparents and friends of the school.The children listened to a iety of stories, some in Welsh, and with many of the storytellers in full costume.Shelley Barrett was dressed as Mole from the Wind in the Willows. She said: "I loved it. The children love being read to and I love doing the dferent voices! I look forward to it every year, choosing the book and my costume. Obviously it helps that I have The Childrenrsquos Costume Studio at The Talent Shack so have access to endless bits and bobs. I was inspired to read Wind in the Willows as the Shelley Norton Stage Schoolis putting it on next month at The Talent Shack."Favourite stories included a dragon, Mary Poppins, an exciting adventure with Toad and some very marvellous medicine.The school managed to get author Elly Grfiths in for the day, working with the Year  and  children.She read extracts from her new book lsquoA Girl Called Justicersquo, and shared insights with the pupils about how to write a good story.At the end of the day, the children and parents were able to buy books from two pop up book stalls on the playgrounds, organised by Grfin Books. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: vale of glamorgan new leader speaks
story: Cllrs Neil Moore And Lis Burnett Taken By Ldr " Vale of Glamorgan: New leader speaksCllrs Neil Moore And Lis Burnett Taken By Ldr " Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentTHE new leader of Vale council has said he will refuse to ldquokowtow to those who shout the loudest and will not be rushed into deciding on controversial proposals such as parking charges.Cllr Neil Moore, who is leading a new Labour-led administration, says it is likely key decisions onproposed parking charges and the lsquoclosurersquo of Llancarfan Primary School will not be made until later this year. He has also cast doubt on the future of the proposed Dinas Powys bypass, and say he believes the Barry Incinerator will be required to draw up an environmental impact assessment ndash which campaigners have been calling for.Cllr Moore and the councilrsquos new deputy leader Lis Burnett gained control of the authority in May.Their priorities include balancing the councilrsquos budget and preserving vital services for the most vulnerable in the face of a need to make pound million of savings over the next two years, as well as regeneration and building more homes, and improving school buildings.Cllr Moore said: ldquoWersquore going to be open and transparent and be prepared to work with people. If there are issues we will try to work through those issues.ldquoSometimes we will have to make decisions that not everyone is going to be happy with.ldquoWe have to be honest with people. We have to say these are the facts and whether we like it or not we will have to do some things dferently or not at all.Cllr Burnett added. ldquoBut we have to be honest about the levels of pressure on local government.ldquoOur priority has to be services to the most vulnerable.The Labour-led coalition includes members of the former Conservative cabinet, which quit the party when former leader John Thomas was deposed as leader of the Vale Tories. The coalition also includes Llantwit First Independents.This is where the new leadership stands on the key issues facing the Vale:Parking chargesCllr Moore said new parking charges proposed by the previous administration, which included town centre car parks, coastal resorts and country parks, will be reviewed.He said new parking charges are likely in the Vale, but they will be ldquorealistic.Cllr Moore said: ldquoWe have to be sensible. Some of the things put forward previously were off the wall, they went too far.ldquoIt will be a full revamp of everything. Whatever we do wersquore not going to fleece the residents of the Vale.ldquoWe may have to make some changes. It does cost money to provide car parking. There are things we will have to start charging for. It will be realistic and fair for everybody.School improvementsThe new cabinet says delivering on major new school buildings is a priority for the new administration.Developments in the pipeline include new builds forPencoedtre and Whitmore High Schools, and expansion and refurbishment of Ysgol Gymraeg Bro MorgannwgAgeing schools in the Vale are set to get a pound. million cash boost for repairs.Llancarfan Primary SchoolLlancarfan Primary School was set to be lsquoclosedrsquoand moved to a new pound million facility in Rhoose.The previous cabinet had approved the plans despite protests from parents and campaigners.Cllr Moore said Llancarfan School move was ldquopremature - but did not commit to scrapping the plan entirely.ldquoIf itrsquos justiable itrsquos justiable, he said. ldquoIf itrsquos not, we will look at alternatives.ldquoItrsquos not an easy decision to take. Itrsquos something we have to take some time about.ldquoWhat Irsquom not going to do is jump or kowtow to people who shout the loudest.Cllr Burnett has previously tweeted the closure of Llancarfan ldquowouldnrsquot be happeningLabour were running the council.New roadsWork continues on outline business cases for two major new roads being proposed ndash the A to M link around Pendoylan and Dinas Powys Bypass between Barry and Cardf ndash but no decision has been made whether either will actually go ahead.The future of both roads rests on whether Welsh Government and the council deem them viable, and whether ministers cough up the cash to fund them.But Cllr Moore said he doesnrsquot think Welsh Government will find the money required for the Dinas Powys Bypass.ldquoItrsquos out of our hands, he said.IncineratorCllr Moore said he believes Welsh Government will order the Barry Biomass incinerator to carry out an environmentalimpact assessment.Cllr Moore, who has previously attacked what he termed ldquoscaremongering and lies around the biomass plant, said he did not want the facility in Barry Docks.He said: ldquoWe opposed it vehemently, both as a council and as a party and personally. It shouldnrsquot be there.ldquoBut now it is there it has to operate within legal parameters.ldquoIf it does, therersquos nothing anyone can do about it.The council refused the original planning permission for the facility, but a planning inspector allowed it in  following an appeal. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: penarth car showroom to be redeveloped into moorwell apartments
story: The art deco car showroom on Windsor Road will soon be home to a collection of  one and two bedroom apartments and duplexes and a penthouse under a scheme named lsquoThe Moorwellrsquo.The creation of local developer Project Three Developments, The Moorwell will see the restoration and conversion of the former car showroom into contemporary homes set around a communal courtyard garden. Anytime Fitness Penarth gym will sit on the ground floor.Savills Cardf will start selling the homes at a price of pound, for a one-bedroom apartment.Built in the s by Stanley Sadler, the building was originally the premises of Sadler Bros Ltd, the successful car garage he ran with his brother, Aubrey Sadler. During the Second World War the building was used as an auxiliary workshop. It changed hands in the early s to become Moorwell Motors.Ben Wells, managing director at Project Three, said: ldquoWe are delighted to reveal our plans to restore and revitalise this impressive Penarth building.ldquoWe were immediately struck by the strong architectural style of the faccedilade and the light and space inside. It was clear there was potential to design a scheme that would honour the buildingrsquos character and heritage, while creating something new and contemporary for future generations to enjoy.Features include double height windows in the duplex and both private and communal outside spaces. A full floor penthouse has a roof terrace to the front and back with panoramic views.Dorothy Foulkes, daughter of Stanley Sadler, who designed and built the distinctive building and ran his business from there for many years, still lives in Penarth and recently visited the site of the development.She said: ldquoI have many memories of the garage over the years. Having stood empty for many years, I am delighted it is being given a new and exciting future. It is wonderful that the key features of the original beautully designed building are being preserved and transformed. It feels very appropriate, given my fatherrsquos very high standards and professionalism that The Moorwell is being designed and constructed with the same values. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice.
